Abstract: To create the X-rays source based on the phenomena of the Compton laser radiation scattering on the relativistic electrons it was a necessity to develop electron storage ring [1] and accelerator-injector with the beam energy 60-100 MeV [2]. The control system of the power supply for the electron linac magnetic system is described in the paper. Programmable current sources equipped with the intellectual CAN-bus (CANopen)[3] controller have been designed for the specific accelerator applications. The control system software was improved to operate with industrial CANopen protocol. The test results of current source are presented.
Index Keywords: Accelerator applications; CANopen protocols; Control system software; Electron linacs; Electron storage ring; Magnetic system; Programmable current; Relativistic electron; Linear accelerators; Storage rings; Control systems

Authors: Korchuganov V., Novikov V., Ushkov V.
Title: First results of the radiation measurements near Siberia-2 storage ring
Source title: RuPAC 2008 Contributions to the Proceedings - 21st Russian Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Korchuganov, V., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Novikov, V., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Ushkov, V., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: When an electron is lost in the storage ring due to a bremsstrahlung it produces high energy photons. These photons, in turn, produce neutrons. In the vicinity of the storage ring the residual radiation field is dominated by these photons and neutrons. The report describes first results of the radiation field measurements. The measurement was carried out by a set of high sensitivity to scattered particles monitors which were placed near the vacuum chamber at critical positions of the ring. The extended use of beam loss monitoring gives a better understanding of the linear and non-linear physics involved in the single and multiple particle dynamics.
Index Keywords: Critical positions; High energy photons; High sensitivity; Multiple particles; Nonlinear physics; Radiation measurements; Residual radiation; Vacuum chambers; Photons; Storage rings; Neutron irradiation

Authors: Anoshin A., Fomin E., Korchuganov V., Krylov Yu., Kvardakov V., Pesterev S., Tomin S., Ushkov V.
Title: A new injection system for kurchatov source of SR
Source title: RuPAC 2008 Contributions to the Proceedings - 21st Russian Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Anoshin, A., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Fomin, E., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Korchuganov, V., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Krylov, Yu., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kvardakov, V., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Pesterev, S., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Tomin, S., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Ushkov, V., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The accelerator complex of the KCSR consists of 2.5 GeV main storage ring, 450 MeV booster storage ring and 80 MeV linac. A project of the complex modernization comprising new brighter optical lattices of main storage ring and new injection system were developed in KCSR. New optical lattices will allow to reduce natural beam emittance from present 100 nm•rad to 18 nm•rad. But due to significant decrease of dynamic aperture the efficiency of injection from the booster storage ring having big natural emittance will be drastically reduced. A new 2.5 GeV booster synchrotron (BS) with 50 nm•rad emittance was developed to overcome this problems. It will be placed in the same tunnel with main ring. Modernization project provides for a possibility to increase injection energy from linac to BS from 80 MeV to 160 MeV by double electron bunches transition through linac structure.
Index Keywords: Accelerator complex; Beam emittance; Booster-synchrotrons; Dynamic aperture; Electron bunch; Injection energy; Injection systems; Modernization projects; Crystal lattices; Linear accelerators; Optical lattices; Optical materials; Particle optics; Storage rings

Authors: Kaportsev E., Krylov Yu., Korchuganov V., Kuznetsov K., Moseiko L., Moseiko N., Yupinov Yu.
Title: The program tools for KSRS operation
Source title: RuPAC 2008 Contributions to the Proceedings - 21st Russian Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kaportsev, E., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Krylov, Yu., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Korchuganov, V., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kuznetsov, K., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Moseiko, L., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Moseiko, N., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Yupinov, Yu., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The running cycle of Kurchatov Synchrotron Radiation Source (KSRS) [1] includes the injection of electrons with energy 80 MeV from the linear accelerator in the booster storage ring Siberia-1, the accumulation of a electron current up to 400 mA and, then, electron energy ramping up to 450 MeV with the subsequent extraction of electrons in the main ring, storage ring Siberia-2, and accumulation there up to 300 mA, and at last the energy ramping up to 2.5 GeV. The control system is based on the distributed network of the processors operating technological systems of KSRS. The operational level of control system is realized as a local network of the personal computer. Instrument of work of the operator is a set of the applied programs realizing the inquiries to the control system. The database describing logic channels of the control, modes of the technological systems and the script of the running cycle of accelerating facilities is developed. Logic channels of the control are a basis for creation of the user interface. The examples of realization of the software used in operative work KSRS are given.
Index Keywords: Applied programs; Distributed networks; Electron currents; Electron energies; Kurchatov synchrotron radiation; Operational level; Running cycles; Technological system; Personal computers; Storage rings; User interfaces; Control systems

Authors: Kvasha A.I., Serov V.L.
Title: Development of the INR DTL RF system crowbar operation
Source title: RuPAC 2008 Contributions to the Proceedings - 21st Russian Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Institute for Nuclear Research, RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kvasha, A.I., Institute for Nuclear Research, RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation; Serov, V.L., Institute for Nuclear Research, RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: DTL RF system of the INR linear accelerator consists of five RF channels. In turn, each channel maintains two powerful series connected vacuum tubes, installed in anode modulator and RF power amplifier PA. Operation of the both tubes is supplied with crowbar system that defends vacuum tubes from destroying as result of breakdowns in one of them. Since the energy storage in the INR DTL anode modulator is artificial forming line AFL (with impedance value 24 Ohm) in crowbar system can be used series thyristors and starting block, which opens the thyristors, when PA vacuum tube anode pulse current exceeds set-point value. In the paper an analysis of the processes in AFL and crowbar system is considered. Some results of the crowbar system upgrade are presented.
Index Keywords: Pulse currents; Rf channels; RF power amplifiers; RF system; Series-connected; Setpoints; System upgrade; Particle accelerators; Thyristors; Vacuum; Tubes (components)

Authors: Struys E.A., Verhoeven-Duif N., Jakobs C.
Title: Creatine and its metabolites
Source title: Laboratory Guide to the Methods in Biochemical Genetics
Affiliations: Clinical Chemistry, Metabolic Unit, VU University Medical Center, 7057, 1007 MB Amsterdam, Netherlands; Department of Metabolic and Endocrine Diseases, University Medical Center Utrecht, Lundlaan 6, 3584 EA Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Struys, E.A., Clinical Chemistry, Metabolic Unit, VU University Medical Center, 7057, 1007 MB Amsterdam, Netherlands; Verhoeven-Duif, N., Department of Metabolic and Endocrine Diseases, University Medical Center Utrecht, Lundlaan 6, 3584 EA Utrecht, Netherlands; Jakobs, C., Clinical Chemistry, Metabolic Unit, VU University Medical Center, 7057, 1007 MB Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: Guanidinoacetate (GA), Creatine (Cr), and creatinine are small polar molecules. It is well recognized that Cr plays an important role in energy transmission and storage in cells and tissues with high energy demand. Recent developments have revealed alteration in the levels of the above-mentioned metabolites in different disease states, i.e. guanidinoacetate methyltransferase (GAMT) deficiency, L-arginine:glycine amidino transferase (AGAT) deficiency and Cr transporter (SLC6A8) deficiency. This group of diseases is referred to as creatine deficiency syndromes (CDS) and can be detected in vivo by 1H magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) of the brain. Quantification of GA and Cr in body fluids forms the biochemical basis for the (differential) diagnosis of the CDS. This current chapter describes a detailed procedure for the simultaneous measurement of GA and Cr in urine, plasma, and cerebrospinal fluid employing Stable-Isotope Dilution Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry. In addition, recent analytical developments using tandem mass spectrometry for the measurement of GA and Cr are briefly discussed. © 2008 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Chiu Y.-C., Riang L., Tseng W.-C., Chou I.-C., Ma C.-C.M.
Title: Thermal stability, and morphology of polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane epoxy nanocomposite
Source title: Progress of Composites 2008 in Asia and Australasia - Proceedings of the 6th Asian-Australasian Conference on Composite Materials, ACCM 2008
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsin-Chu 30043, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chiu, Y.-C., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsin-Chu 30043, Taiwan; Riang, L., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsin-Chu 30043, Taiwan; Tseng, W.-C., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsin-Chu 30043, Taiwan; Chou, I.-C., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsin-Chu 30043, Taiwan; Ma, C.-C.M., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsin-Chu 30043, Taiwan
Abstract: Isocyanatopropyldimethylsilyl-Isobutyl-POSS and DGEBA epoxy were utilized to prepare a novel POSS-Epoxy (IPEP). The chemical structure was determined by FTIR-ATR and Solid-state 29Si-NMR. The char yield was increased with the IPEP content in nitrogen or air atmosphere. Meanwhile, the silica char not only provided thermal insulation but also the anti-oxidant property. The activation energies of thermal degradation were calculated by Ozawa and Kissinger's method. In nitrogen atmosphere, the energy values were 159.7∼193.81 kJ/mol and 165.5∼200.69 kJ/mol, and in air atmosphere, the values were 98.67-134.08 kJ/mol and 138.49∼281.55 kJ/mol by Ozawa and Kissinger's method, respectively. The activation energies were increased with IPEP moiety. SEM, EDX, and TEM confirmed that the inorganic silica segments (POSS) of IPEP nanocomposites were dispersed uniformly and no phase aggregation occurred. Furthermore, the size domain of POSS was less than 5 nm. The XRD photography showed a broad peak about 14∼15°, the phenomenon resulted from the chain entanglement of the epoxy/amine curing reaction. From the mechanical properties investigations, the bulky POSS cage side chain might interrupt the cross-linking structure of the curing reaction of the epoxy/amine. And the storage modulus and the hardness tests would be decreased with the higher IPEP content.
Author Keywords: Morphology; Nanocomposite; POSS; Thermal stability
Index Keywords: Antioxidant properties; Chain entanglements; Cross-linking structures; Curing reactions; Epoxy nanocomposites; Nitrogen atmospheres; Polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxanes; POSS; Activation energy; Chains; Composite materials; Crosslinking; Curing; Mechanical properties; Morphology; Nitrogen; Silica; Thermodynamic stability; Nanocomposites

Authors: Jeong Y., Cha S., Jang J., Hong S.
Title: Fabrication process of highly porous carbon nanofibers web implanted with carbon nanotubes for supercapacitor application
Source title: Advances in Powder Metallurgy and Particulate Materials - 2008, Proceedings of the 2008 World Congress on Powder Metallurgy and Particulate Materials, PowderMet 2008
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon 305-701, South Korea; Advanced Materials and Application Research Division, 70 Boolmosangil, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Jeong, Y., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon 305-701, South Korea; Cha, S., Advanced Materials and Application Research Division, 70 Boolmosangil, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Jang, J., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon 305-701, South Korea; Hong, S., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon 305-701, South Korea
Abstract: Supercapacitors have been intensively investigated as energy storage systems because they can delivery high power and have long lifecycles. Their storage ability depends on the types and forms of the electrode materials. Recently, polyacrylonitrile (PAN) polymer was used as the precursor of the fibrous carbon materials by electrospinning process. However, PAN was known to be difficult for controlling the pore size and surface properties of the obtained carbon fibers. In addition, carbon fiber s from PAN didn't enhance the efficiency of supercapacitor electrode because most of them consist of micropores. In this study, we utilized the natural ability of the amylase and amylopectin polymer chains within corn starch to assemble into as organized nanoscale lamellar structure, which consists of crystalline and amorphous regions, to obtain porous carbon nanofibers. We also used carbon nanotubes as reinforcements to enhance mechanical properties of carbon nanofiber webs. Carbon nanofiber web implanted with carbon nanotubes consists of highly porous surface structure by controlling the carbonization temperature.© 2008 Metal Powder Industries Federation.
Index Keywords: Carbonization temperatures; Electrospinning process; Energy storage systems; Fabrication process; Polyacrylonitrile (PAN); Porous carbon nanofibers; Supercapacitor application; Supercapacitor electrodes; Carbon fibers; Carbon nanofibers; Carbonization; Electrolytic capacitors; Mechanical properties; Nanostructures; Powder metallurgy; Carbon nanotubes

Authors: Yoo S.Y., Park C.H., Choi S.K., Noh M.
Title: Identification of flexible rotor model for a large capacity flywheel energy storage system
Source title: 15th International Congress on Sound and Vibration 2008, ICSV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Mechatronics Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, 305-764, South Korea; Electromagnetic Machinery Research Team, Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials, Daejeon, 305-343, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Yoo, S.Y., Department of Mechatronics Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, 305-764, South Korea; Park, C.H., Electromagnetic Machinery Research Team, Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials, Daejeon, 305-343, South Korea; Choi, S.K., Electromagnetic Machinery Research Team, Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials, Daejeon, 305-343, South Korea; Noh, M., Department of Mechatronics Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, 305-764, South Korea
Abstract: When we design a controller for the active magnetic bearings that support a large rotor, it is important to have an accurate model of the rotor. For the case of the flywheel that is used to store energy, an accurate rotor model is especially important because the dynamics change with respect to the running speed due to gyroscopic effects. In this paper, we present a procedure of obtaining an accurate rotor model of a large flywheel energy storage system using finite-element method. The model can predict the first and the second bending mode which match well with the experimental results obtained from a prototype flywheel energy storage system.
Index Keywords: Accurate modeling; Active Magnetic Bearing; Bending modes; Flexible rotors; Flywheel energy storage system; Gyroscopic Effects; Rotor model; Running speed; Flywheel propulsion; Finite element method

Authors: Lipson A.G., Roussetski A.S., Lyakhov B.F., Saunin E.I., Sakov D.M., Tsivadze A.Yu.
Title: Novel highly D-loaded/high D-diffusivity nanostructured materials on the PD substrate as a potential media to enhance low energy nuclear reactions
Source title: Proceedings of the 13th International Conference on Condensed Matter Nuclear Science, ICCF 2007
Affiliations: Institute of Physical Chemistry and Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 119991, Russian Federation; P.N. Lebedev Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 119991, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Lipson, A.G., Institute of Physical Chemistry and Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 119991, Russian Federation; Roussetski, A.S., P.N. Lebedev Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 119991, Russian Federation; Lyakhov, B.F., Institute of Physical Chemistry and Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 119991, Russian Federation; Saunin, E.I., Institute of Physical Chemistry and Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 119991, Russian Federation; Sakov, D.M., Institute of Physical Chemistry and Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 119991, Russian Federation; Tsivadze, A.Yu., Institute of Physical Chemistry and Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 119991, Russian Federation
Abstract: In order to enhance LENR effects in Pd-D system, two novel highly D- loaded/ high D-diffusivity materials containing multilayer structures deposited on top of Pd substrate have been explored. The first composite material synthesized in our Laboratory is representing a high capacity hydrogen storage media consisting of Single Wall carbon nanotube (SWCNT) layer encapsulated by thin Pd films electrodeposited on top of Pd foil (Pd-SWCNT composite). The second cathode material is a multilayer Pd-Re-Pd-Re structure electrodeposited on top of 50 micron Pd foil (Pd-Re multilayer). Results on nuclear emissions from Pd-SWCNT and Pd-Re multilayer cathodes during D-desorption showed that these novel materials are enable to enhance the LENR effects in deuterated solids and could be used as new type of cathodes allowing to trigger and enhance fusion reactions (compared to pristine Pd) during electrolysis.
Index Keywords: Cath-ode materials; High capacity; Hydrogen storage media; Low energy nuclear reactions; Multilayer structures; Novel materials; Nuclear emissions; Pd foils; Composite films; Electrodeposition; Hydrogen storage; Multilayers; Nuclear physics; Solids; Cathodes

Authors: Vance J.E., Adeli K.
Title: Assembly and secretion of triacylglycerol-rich lipoproteins
Source title: Biochemistry of Lipids, Lipoproteins and Membranes
Affiliations: Group on Molecular and Cell Biology of Lipids, Department of Medicine, Heritage Medical Research Center, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G 2S2, Canada; Molecular Structure and Function Research Institute, The Hospital for Sick Children, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON M5G1X8, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Vance, J.E., Group on Molecular and Cell Biology of Lipids, Department of Medicine, Heritage Medical Research Center, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G 2S2, Canada; Adeli, K., Molecular Structure and Function Research Institute, The Hospital for Sick Children, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON M5G1X8, Canada
Abstract: The triacylglycerol (TG)-rich lipoproteins (very low-density lipoproteins (VLDLs) and chylomicrons (CM)) are secreted into the circulation by hepatocytes of the liver and enter ocytes of the intestine. All plasma lipoproteins share a common structure with a neutral lipid core, consisting of TGs and cholesteryl esters, surrounded by a surface monolayer of phospholipids, unesterified cholesterol, and specific proteins, known as apolipoproteins (apos). The primary function of plasma lipoproteins is to transport hydrophobic, water-insoluble lipids within the circulation to other tissues. The TG-rich lipoproteins contain apo B and deliver TGs made in the liver and intestine to other tissues in the body for either storage or utilization as an energy source. VLDLs and CM can be converted into low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) in the circulation. Lipoproteins remove cholesterol from tissues for delivery to the liver and excretion into bile in a process termed "reverse cholesterol transport." In general, a high level of plasma LDL is a strong risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease whereas a high level of HDL is protective. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Moran A., Skinner B.
Title: Resource adequacy and efficient infrastructure investment
Affiliations: Institute of Public Affairs (IPA), Australia; TRUenergy, Melbourne, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Moran, A., Institute of Public Affairs (IPA), Australia, TRUenergy, Melbourne, Australia; Skinner, B., Institute of Public Affairs (IPA), Australia, TRUenergy, Melbourne, Australia
Abstract: This chapter examines the concerns about resource adequacy in the context of the "energy-only" Australian National Electricity Market (NEM). It argues that the NEM has worked well. Prices have remained among the lowest in the world, reliability has been maintained, and the market has produced new generation investment of the magnitude, type, and timing that has been appropriate. These results point to the superiority, at least in the Australian context, of an energy-only market approach that operates without the potential distortions that separate capacity payments bring. Among the many issues with which electricity market designers have wrestled is how to ensure reliable and uninterrupted supply. The concerns cover short-run operations and longer-term investment adequacy. Electricity is jointly supplied to the whole community, has virtually no storage capabilities, and faces a peaky demand with little capacity or desire of consumers to respond to excess demand (and hence price surges) by reducing their demand. In addition, it is subject to political oversight of prices and many facets of supply. Many have argued that as a result there will be "missing money" in the market and that we must, therefore, have a dual market for electricity generation, covering energy on the one hand and capacity on the other. Similar issues are present with electricity transmission where virtually all markets involve forms of regulated supply. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved.

Authors: Reynaud J.F., Alonso C., Aloisi P., Cabal C., Estibals B., Rigobert G., Sarre G., Rouault H., Mourzagh D., Mattera F., Genies S.
Title: Multifunctional module lithium-ion storage and photovoltaic conversion of solar energy
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: CNRS, Laboratory for Analysis and Architecture of Systems (LAAS), France; SAFT, France; CEA-LITEN, Laboratory for Energy Compounds (LCE), France; INES-RDI, CEA-LITEN, Laboratory for Solar Systems (L2S), France
Authors with affiliations: Reynaud, J.F., CNRS, Laboratory for Analysis and Architecture of Systems (LAAS), France; Alonso, C., CNRS, Laboratory for Analysis and Architecture of Systems (LAAS), France; Aloisi, P., CNRS, Laboratory for Analysis and Architecture of Systems (LAAS), France; Cabal, C., CNRS, Laboratory for Analysis and Architecture of Systems (LAAS), France; Estibals, B., CNRS, Laboratory for Analysis and Architecture of Systems (LAAS), France; Rigobert, G., SAFT, France; Sarre, G., SAFT, France; Rouault, H., CEA-LITEN, Laboratory for Energy Compounds (LCE), France; Mourzagh, D., CEA-LITEN, Laboratory for Energy Compounds (LCE), France; Mattera, F., INES-RDI, CEA-LITEN, Laboratory for Solar Systems (L2S), France; Genies, S., INES-RDI, CEA-LITEN, Laboratory for Solar Systems (L2S), France
Abstract: A large part of photovoltaic research is dedicated to developing innovative integration technology for the module. Now the use of a storage function in such intermittent power supply systems is crucial in order to get better adequacy between the peaks of energetic consumption and production. The integration degree of photovoltaic systems will be improved if all the components: panel, battery, converters, electronic control unit, cablings can be combined in a compact single unit. Different battery technologies are currently used with photovoltaic systems along with some of the charging and discharging techniques that are available. Lithium-ion technology appears to be the best candidate because of its high energetic efficiency, high specific energy density, deep discharge ability, its long cycling life and its possible different shapes (cylindrical or prismatic styles) to obtain an integrated design. To optimize the battery performance, different conditions are required and achieved by control sub-systems, integrated into battery and module construction. The electronic management system presented in this paper aims to optimize the use of the battery making the overall system more reliable and cost effective. On the one hand, a research algorithm of the optimal power to charge and discharge an advanced lithium-ion battery for photovoltaic application is necessary to obtain an optimum electronic management system. On the other hand, a Maximum Power Point Tracking is also incorporated into the electronic control unit, to optimize the solar array production under varying atmospheric conditions. This paper will describe a new concept of an integrated multifunctional module using lithium-ion batteries and new control algorithms. © 2008 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Advanced lithium-ion batteries; Electronic control units; Integration technologies; Lithium-ion technology; Maximum Power Point Tracking; Photovoltaic applications; Photovoltaic conversion; Specific energy density; Algorithms; Electric power systems; Lithium alloys; Lithium batteries; Management; Optimization; Photovoltaic cells; Charging (batteries)

Authors: Jayalakshmi M., Balasubramanian K.
Title: Simple capacitors to supercapacitors - An overview
Affiliations: Non-Ferrous Materials Technology Development Centre (NFTDC), Kanchanbagh Post, Hyderabad- 500058, India
Authors with affiliations: Jayalakshmi, M., Non-Ferrous Materials Technology Development Centre (NFTDC), Kanchanbagh Post, Hyderabad- 500058, India; Balasubramanian, K., Non-Ferrous Materials Technology Development Centre (NFTDC), Kanchanbagh Post, Hyderabad- 500058, India
Abstract: The renaissance of electrical/electrochemical double layer capacitors is occurring at a phenomenally high rate as the significant role of these power storage devices in traction, space flight technology, power electronics and other related fields is recognized. The needs of to-day's computer world cannot be fulfilled by the conventional capacitors such as electrostatic and electrolytic capacitors as their utility is limited to certain specific applications. Electric double layer capacitor (EDLC) uses carbon as the electrodes and stores charge in the electric field at the interface. It uses either aqueous or nonaqueous electrolyte. It gives high power density but low energy density. So the next generation electrochemical double layer capacitor or super capacitor which uses transition metal oxide as the electrode material along with carbon has been under innovation which is expected to deliver both desirable power and energy densities. In this overview, an attempt to provide information on the chronological order of development of capacitors and the related research work is made. © 2008 by ESG.
Author Keywords: Ceramic capacitor; Electrical double layer capacitor; Electrolytic capacitor; Electrostatic capacitor; Super capacitor

Authors: Fusco G., Pastena M., D'Errico M.
Title: Integrated Li-ion cells/super-capacitors modular battery system
Source title: International Astronautical Federation - 59th International Astronautical Congress 2008, IAC 2008
Affiliations: Carlo Gavazzi Space S.p.A, Satellite Projects Department, via Tiengo snc, 82100 Benevento, Italy; Seconda Universita di Napoli, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Aerospaziale e Meccanica, via Roma 29, 81031 Aversa (CE), Italy
Authors with affiliations: Fusco, G., Carlo Gavazzi Space S.p.A, Satellite Projects Department, via Tiengo snc, 82100 Benevento, Italy; Pastena, M., Carlo Gavazzi Space S.p.A, Satellite Projects Department, via Tiengo snc, 82100 Benevento, Italy; D'Errico, M., Seconda Universita di Napoli, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Aerospaziale e Meccanica, via Roma 29, 81031 Aversa (CE), Italy
Abstract: In case of satellite missions characterized by high peak power requests, the battery system is usually oversized in order to provide the needed peak discharge currents. The integration of supercapacitors with battery cells optimizes power supply of satellite equipments requiring very high power for short times (such as SARs, mechanisms, and transmitters), i.e. it can increase battery lifetime and involve a significant mass reduction of the satellite energy storage system. Such mass saving is a function of peak power/average power ratio. Supercapacitors are electrochemical devices able to store energy through a physical process. The absence of chemical reactions grants higher power densities and higher charge/discharge currents, but lower energy densities with reference to common battery cells. Such characteristics make supercapacitors particularly suitable for the integration in hybrid energy storage systems, e.g. to support Li-ion battery cells in case of peak power requests. It is worth noting that the integration of electrochemical capacitors with satellite battery cells requests an accurate evaluation of the problem areas related to the use of such technology in the space environment and of the impacts on both Electrical Power Subsystem and Spacecraft System design.
Index Keywords: Electrical power subsystems; Electrochemical capacitor; Electrochemical devices; Hybrid energy storage systems; Satellite equipment; Satellite mission; Space environment; Spacecraft system; Capacitors; Energy storage; Integration; Lithium; Satellites; Spacecraft power supplies; Lithium batteries

Authors: Canazza V., Gianotti C., Venturini A.
Title: Cross border electricity exchanges between Italy, Switzerland and Germany: Scenarios of competition among the European power markets and signals for interconnection investments
Source title: 42nd International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems 2008, CIGRE 2008
Affiliations: Worldenergy Sa, Switzerland; CESI Spa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Canazza, V.; Gianotti, C., Worldenergy Sa, Switzerland; Venturini, A., CESI Spa, Italy
Abstract: From winter 2005-2006 till December 2007, Italy has become a net power exporter for at least three times, thus reversing the traditional import flow from cheaper central European markets to the Italian market. Such power exports have been caused in part by exceptional conditions, in partly by structural changes, such as insufficient reserve at peak load in some central European countries and conversely increasing reserve in Italy. The price difference between the Ipex (Italian Power Exchange) and the central European exchanges is a consequence of the different production mix, primarily based on gas-fired power plants in Italy. Italian power prices are thus strongly driven by: (a) the variable generation costs (i.e. the gas cost including variable transportation costs and taxes), and (b) the investment costs in the power plant, which can only be recovered if the market price exceeds the variable cost. Prices between the two areas will tend to converge, as producers in Central Europe try to rapidly develop new capacity to increase the reserve margin at peak times. However, opportunities for power exchange between the two areas will remain. Possible power flows are however constrained, in the north to south direction, at two points, one at the German / Swiss border, the other one at the Swiss / Italian border. This paper proposes an hourly analysis of expected cross border exchanges between the Italian electric system and the Swiss / German one for the year 2012, taking into account different marginal prices and congestions. Hourly prices in Italy have been determined by using the NEWPROMED software, a simulator of the electricity market on a yearly horizon. Hourly prices in Central Europe (Eex) have been generated by means of statistical analysis based on the quoted forward values at the Eex. The auction premium to be paid at the German / Swiss border (direction north to south) causes a bid / ask spread at the Italian border. Such auction premium is in turn dependent on Italian market prices. The analysis of past data shows that the auction premium has been overstated in several hours. Some predictions can be made based on the analysis of Italian market prices in 2012 and on oil price scenarios.
Author Keywords: Bidding strategy; Cross border trading; Electricity market; Energy trading; European power markets; Investment signals; Italian Power Exchange; Market simulator; Price forecasting; Transfer capacity
Index Keywords: Bidding strategy; Cross-border trading; Electricity market; Energy trading; Market simulators; Power exchange; Power markets; Price forecasting; Transfer capacities; Computer software; Cost accounting; Costs; Digital storage; Electric industry; Electricity; International trade; Power plants; Investments

Authors: Mauri G., Moneta D.
Title: Management and control of the interaction between small active customers and the LV grid: A metropolitan case study
Source title: 42nd International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems 2008, CIGRE 2008
Affiliations: CESI RICERCA, Italy; Salvatore Pugliese, Stefano Fratti - A2A, Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Mauri, G., CESI RICERCA, Italy; Moneta, D., Salvatore Pugliese, Stefano Fratti - A2A, Milan, Italy
Abstract: The process of opening the energy market already reached small business and residential consumers. Several opportunities are now available for small energy users which are about to change their role of passive consumers becoming active customers. Continuous increase of energy demand and the recent peak-shifting from winter to summer especially in urban areas represent new challenges for distribution utilities. Not always network upgrade is possible, often it is neither the more efficient solution. Forecast of the capacity improvement and planning of the most adequate investment is always necessary. An analysis on the Milan urban area and a comparison with regional and national data is reported. A simple model is then proposed to support the planning process. Steep increasing in demand and inadequacy of the distribution network can be temporarily mitigated by short term-actions like promotion of energy efficiency in end-uses and providing customers and households with the technology enabling them to become "active nodes" of the electric network. Responding customers, in a liberalized market scenario, may offer services both to the network (power modulation) and to the market (reduce energy price volatility). The interaction between customers and distribution networks can be provided by a local ICT platform (at customer side) which supports both energy management and bi-directional communication with energy retailers, traders and distributors. This ICT platform receives market and system signals from distribution utilities, energy traders and retailers and provides energy management of loads, HVAC (Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning) systems, storages, local generation units according to user preferences.
Author Keywords: Demand side initiatives; DER; Energy efficiency; RES
Index Keywords: Bi-directional communication; Demand-side; DER; Distribution utilities; Energy price volatilities; Management and controls; RES; Ventilation and air conditioning; Air conditioning; Circuit theory; Commerce; Energy efficiency; Energy management; Heating; Sales; Urban planning; Investments

Authors: Sánchez E., Anduaga J., Santiago F.J., Gil De Muro A.
Title: Microgrids integration into the distribution network
Source title: 42nd International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems 2008, CIGRE 2008
Affiliations: LABEIN-TECNALIA, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Sánchez, E., LABEIN-TECNALIA, Spain; Anduaga, J., LABEIN-TECNALIA, Spain; Santiago, F.J., LABEIN-TECNALIA, Spain; Gil De Muro, A., LABEIN-TECNALIA, Spain
Abstract: This paper describes the work carried out in the frame of the Spanish MICROGRID project, aiming the study of interaction between an electrical microgrid and the electrical distribution system taking into account both the isolated and the grid connected modes. The general objective is to foster the development of new products for the electrical grid of the future, considering the technical requirements and interconnection standards. Also regulatory and socioeconomic aspects are considered in the project. The paper shows the main results of the project during the simulation and construction phases. In the simulation phase it has been proved that: the state estimation algorithms used at the transmission network are also applicable at the distribution network; DER (Distributed Energy Resources) integration can contribute to reduce load flow through the lines, under a certain installed power level; an adequate control system would permit DER installations to generate energy above the legally established limits without causing problems to the network. The microgrid construction phase has been developed in the Technology Park of Bizkaia (TPB), placed in the North of Spain, where several partners have their facilities. The main activities, supported by site tests and carried on in this installation are: the monitoring of the microgrid using the standard protocol (IEC 61850 part. 7-420); the assessment of the impact of the microgrid on the transformation centre; the switching between connected and isolated mode; the microgrid power quality and stability improvement; the connection of fuel cell to the grid. The main contribution to the TPB microgrid has been the DER technologies demonstration facility located in LABEIN-TECNALIA's premises. It consists on an installation connected to the low voltage network and integrated by several generation and storage technologies together with programmable loads and grid simulators. The project has been developed during 3 years, June-2004 to June-2007 and has been partially supported by the Spanish Government (Ministerio de Educación y Ciencia), Basque Government and Bizkaia Local Administration. Around ten companies and technological centres have joined the project which has been promoted by the Basque Country Energy Cluster, the Basque Energy Agency, Iberdrola and Tecnalia Technology Corporation. The involved industrial and technological companies are: Iberdrola, Arteche, Ingelectric, Intekia, Labein-Tecnalia, Ormazabal, Robotiker-Tecnalia, Sevilla of University, Team-Arteche, Zigor, ZIV p+c and Air Liquide España.
Author Keywords: DER Integration; Energy Controller; Interconnection Standard; Local Controller; Microgrid; Microgrid Controller; Microgrid Stability; State Estimation

Authors: Park S.-K., Lee J., Jun B.-H., Lee P.-M.
Title: A new method for AUV's homing path planning
Affiliations: BK21 Mechatronics Group at Chungnam National University, 220 Gung-dong, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 305-761, South Korea; Korea Research Institute of Ships and Ocean Engineering, KORDI, 171 Jang-dong, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 305-343, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, S.-K., BK21 Mechatronics Group at Chungnam National University, 220 Gung-dong, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 305-761, South Korea; Lee, J., BK21 Mechatronics Group at Chungnam National University, 220 Gung-dong, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 305-761, South Korea; Jun, B.-H., Korea Research Institute of Ships and Ocean Engineering, KORDI, 171 Jang-dong, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 305-343, South Korea; Lee, P.-M., Korea Research Institute of Ships and Ocean Engineering, KORDI, 171 Jang-dong, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 305-343, South Korea
Abstract: Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) and Remotely Operated Vehicles (ROVs) are useful for many underwater operations such as collecting biological and mineral resources; however there are some limitations for those vehicles during long-term operations. Although studies have been made of AUVs over the past thirty years, still AUV technology limitations remain. Due to the current state of computational capability and data storage capacity, the technology can marginally provide fair speed and efficiency including well-established software developments. Energy storage and power consumptions are critical factors for all long-term operations. In the long-term underwater application, docking operation is important for recharging power and transferring data which are limited by the onboard energy storage and on-board data storage. The general problem of accurately stabilizing the position and orientation of the underwater vehicle is a key problem of homing path planning. In this paper, we propose the Virtual Goal Method based on AUV's bounded turning radius and tangent points. Simulation result shows that this planner is very fast and guaranteed the AUV's homing orientation and position.

Authors: Klöckl B., Papaefthymiou G., Pinson P.
Title: Probabilistic tools for planning and operating power systems with distributed energy storage
Source title: 42nd International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems 2008, CIGRE 2008
Affiliations: Market Management, Verbund APG, Austria; Electrical Power Systems, TU Delft, Netherlands; DTU Informatics, Kgs. Lyngby, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Klöckl, B., Market Management, Verbund APG, Austria; Papaefthymiou, G., Electrical Power Systems, TU Delft, Netherlands; Pinson, P., DTU Informatics, Kgs. Lyngby, Denmark
Abstract: stochastic energy flows are an increasingly important phenomenon in today's power system planning and operation. They are-among other reasons-caused by large amounts of stochastic generation such as wind. The inclusion of energy storage devices, distributed in future systems (distributed energy storage-DES), is continuously being mentioned as a possibility to alleviate some of the problems arising from stochastic generation. The authors show that the potential ownership of the DES systems is an important criterion on which probabilistic methods will be applied for assessment. The potential owners are either the grid operators, the generation owners, or the energy traders. For the grid operators being the DES owners, storage operation will have to be integrated into the planning of the system, therefore multivariate nonparametric time series analysis and synthesis methods have to be applied to recorded data of stochastic energy resources. Together with suited storage models, the implications of DES on the planning of the system can then be assessed. For the producers or traders being the owners of the DES, the topic to be addressed is the real-time operation of each storage device in the power system, which is linked to the optimisation of the economic value of the stochastic resources. In this case, forecasting and operations research issues are paramount. Recently developed methods including scenario development from non-parametric forecast models for the following trading period and probabilistic assessment of necessary storage capacities for hedging with given financial risks are explained. It is generally stated that the non-standard distributions of the stochastic infeeds, as well as complex chronological persistence and interdependence phenomena complicate the modelling procedure and leave space for a large range of research activities on DES in the future. The exact description of how the owners of storage assets are embedded into the energy market frameworks of the future is crucial for the probabilistic quantification of benefits introduced by DES.
Author Keywords: Correlation; Energy storage; Forecasting; Operation; Planning; Renewable energy; Stochastic generation; Wind power
Index Keywords: Distributed energy storages; Non-parametric forecasts; Operation; Power system planning and operation; Probabilistic assessments; Probabilistic quantification; Renewable energies; Stochastic generation; Commerce; Digital storage; Electric power transmission networks; Energy resources; Energy storage; Forecasting; Operations research; Optical correlation; Planning; Risk perception; Time series analysis; Wind power; Stochastic systems

Authors: Abbey C., Chahwan J., Chamberland M., Joos G.
Title: Planning and operation of energy storage for the integration of wind energy
Source title: 42nd International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems 2008, CIGRE 2008
Affiliations: McGill University, Canada; Natural Resources, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Abbey, C., McGill University, Canada; Chahwan, J., McGill University, Canada; Chamberland, M., Natural Resources, Canada; Joos, G., McGill University, Canada
Abstract: Installed wind energy in North America still lags behind its European counterparts. However, Canada will likely become one of the top wind energy producers worldwide, because of its significant wind resources. However, there are obstacles to the widespread deployment and integration of wind energy, many are a result of the nature of Canadian electricity systems-a relatively small number of large load centres with long transmission lines-but also due to problems that have been experienced elsewhere, such as capacity constraints due to the remote nature of good wind resources. The growth of wind and the associated challenges that it imposes on the planning and operation of power systems will need to be carefully weighed as the evolution of Canadian power systems is charted. Options, including energy storage in one form or another, for mitigating negative impacts of large amounts of intermittent generation need to be compared, considering the overall value that is brought to the power system and the costs incurred. In this paper, we will consider energy storage, particularly in the form of battery storage, as a means of facilitating the integration of wind energy into remote communities and distribution systems. Drawing on Canadian expertise, the planning of energy storage projects will be discussed from the technical and economic standpoints. The tools that are presently in use and near-term research efforts are summarized. The intent is to provide a picture of the current state-of-the-art and an idea of the future direction of storage technologies.
Author Keywords: Battery storage; Energy storage benefits; Energy storage sizing; Wind energy integration
Index Keywords: Battery storage; Capacity constraints; Distribution systems; Economic standpoints; Operation of power system; Remote communities; Storage technology; Wind energy integration; Electric power systems; Electricity; Energy storage; Integration; Wind power

Authors: Micolano E., Bossi C., Valli C., Verga M.
Title: Experimental tests on storage systems in a distributed generation microgrid
Source title: 42nd International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems 2008, CIGRE 2008
Affiliations: CESI RICERCA, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Micolano, E., CESI RICERCA, Italy; Bossi, C., CESI RICERCA, Italy; Valli, C., CESI RICERCA, Italy; Verga, M., CESI RICERCA, Italy
Abstract: Energy storage systems are generally present in distributed generation (DG) grids and are particularly important in renewable energy generators installations in order to decouple energy availability and demand and for the stability of a microgrid in islanding operation. The paper presents the results of an experimental activity on different typologies of storage systems, based on electrical energy storage and fuel storage. The various storage technologies have been characterized in laboratory tests and afterward have been installed and connected to a low voltage grid test facility used for distributed generation studies and analysis. The test facility consists of conventional and innovative renewable energy generators, co-generators plants, fuel cells, controllable loads, traditional and innovative electrical energy storage systems including electrochemical and mechanical equipments, such as a lead acid battery, ZEBRA™ batteries, a high speed flywheel, a Vanadium Redox Flow battery. The distributed resources can be connected at different points of an automated LV grid working in radial, ring and meshed configuration. Experimental activity and tests results are described in the paper. In particular storage systems characterisation tests and performances verification at different operating and ambient conditions are reported, including systems reliability. Tests performed in test facility were also focused on energy storage systems management in a DG grid, demonstrating possible applications and evaluating systems performances both in islanding operation and connected to the main grid. In particular overall systems managing tools have been developed and tested for grid operation. The experimental results concerning a diagnostic tool for on-line estimation of the state of health (SOH) of VRLA and ZEBRA™ batteries are also reported. In addition to electrical energy storage systems, hydrogen storage systems have been designed and tested, coupled to PEM fuel cell and connected to the DG test facility. Hydrogen storage systems developed in our laboratories use metal hydride technology (La-Ni or Mg based) that allows hydrogen storage at low pressures. Different storage tanks with hydrogen capacity from 150 to 6500 Nl have been designed and tested. In particular a storage system with a volume of about 30 l and filled with 50 kg of metal hydride (LaNi based), operating at a pressure between 1 to 6 bars and in a temperature range between 10 and 70C, characterised by a hydrogen storage capacity of 6500 Nl (energy storage of about 19 kWh) has been developed. The same hydrogen capacity can be obtained with a 30 l compressed bottle operating at about 200 bar. The storage system has been previously tested in a stand-alone configuration verifying hydrogen charge and discharge cycles characteristics at different pressure and temperature conditions and evaluating negligible performance degradation after about 100 cycles. Afterward hydrogen storage system has been connected to a 3 kW PEM fuel cell in order to demonstrate that fuel cell heat losses can be recovered and used by the storage system during hydrogen discharge phase. Several tests at different fuel cell load conditions have been tested; storage system allowed operating fuel cell at nominal load for about 3 hours. The work has been financed by the Ministry of Economic Development with the Research Fund of the Italian Electrical System under the Contract Agreement established with the Ministry Decree of March 23, 2006.
Author Keywords: Distributed generation; Electrical energy storage; Fuel cell; Hydrogen storage; Peak shaving; Power quality; Renewable energy; SOH-State Of Health; Test facility

Authors: Kao T.-M., Weng C.-S.
Title: Applications of quantitative risk assessment technique on Liquefied Natural Gas tank systems
Source title: 9th International Conference on Probabilistic Safety Assessment and Management 2008, PSAM 2008
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, Taoyuan County, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Kao, T.-M., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, Taoyuan County, Taiwan; Weng, C.-S., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, Taoyuan County, Taiwan
Abstract: According to the Taiwan's Council of Labor Affairs (TCLA) Act 132 entitled, "Safety Inspection Rules for Dangerous Machines and Equipments", the Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) tank is a specific facility for the storage of high-pressure gas and an internal inspection should be implemented by the end of a 15 year period. The first three LNG tanks in Taiwan in operation from 1990 till 2006 have exceeded the time limit for an internal inspection as required by law. Since Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER), Taiwan has accumulated over 25 years' matured Probabilistic/Quantitative Risk Assessment (PRA/QRA) experience on nuclear power plants, the TCLA encourages utilities to implement QRA on LNG tank systems as an alternative to the required internal surveillance inspection. The TCLA granted the Taiwan Chinese Petroleum Corp. (TCPC) with 2 additional years of extension in March 2007, depending on the final results of the QRA of the LNG tank systems in this study. The TCPC saved more than 60 million U.S. Dollars of direct costs with the exemption of periodic inspections of LNG tanks. The primary initiating events source of LNG tank system from this QRA study attribute to the leakage of auxiliary piping of the LNG tank systems. The ratio of initiating events caused by the leakage of LNG tank membrane is lower than 1% within the period of 10 years. The LNG tank membrane is not the major source of initiating events. From the viewpoint of risk, the probability of leakage on LNG tank membrane will grow with time. However, due to the small amount of LNG leakage and the small impact area, the contribution of initiating events caused by LNG tank membrane failure on the F-N (Frequency-Number of Fatalities) curve of Individual Risk and Societal Risk is minor. The operating risk of the LNG receiving terminal will not be significantly affected with respect to the exemption of internal inspections on LNG tank membrane. The QRA technique has demonstrated its effectiveness in helping managers to make decision on the base of associated risk information and to optimize the resource taking full consideration between safety and operation requirements.
Author Keywords: Liquefied Natural Gas; Quantitative Risk Assessment; Tank system

Authors: Vivalda C., Jammes L.
Title: Probabilistic performance assessment methodology for long term subsurface CO2 storage
Source title: 9th International Conference on Probabilistic Safety Assessment and Management 2008, PSAM 2008
Affiliations: Schumberger Carbon Services, Clamart, France; Schlumberger Carbon Services, Paris La Defense, France
Authors with affiliations: Vivalda, C., Schumberger Carbon Services, Clamart, France; Jammes, L., Schlumberger Carbon Services, Paris La Defense, France
Abstract: Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) is a promising technology to help mitigate climate change by way of reducing atmospheric greenhouse gas emissions. CCS involves capturing CO2 from large industrial or energy-related sources, transporting, and injecting it into the subsurface for long term storage. One of the main challenges of this action is to guarantee that the storage site performs and will continue to perform according to the initial requirements. Site performance is measured by storage capacity, injectivity, and containment of injected CO2. Due to the limited knowledge and feedback experience about CO2 behaviour during and after injection, new predictive methods to assess site performance throughout its lifecycle (thousands of years) are starting to be developed. Within this frame, the paper will present a methodology that uses risk assessment as a driver. The core of the methodology is the identification of the possible short/mid/long-term losses of performance of the system, their description in terms of reference risk pathways, defined as the mechanism of exposure of a receptor to a stressor, and their probabilistic quantification. The current limited knowledge of the site and of the behaviour of CO2 underground introduces a large amount of uncertainty on the initial conditions and input parameters and the methodology aims at determining how this uncertainty affects the final results.
Author Keywords: CO2 subsurface storage; Performance assessment; Risk scenarios; Uncertainty analysis
Index Keywords: Atmospheric greenhouse; Carbon capture and storage; Initial conditions; Performance assessment; Predictive methods; Probabilistic performance; Probabilistic quantification; Risk scenarios; Carbon capture; Climate change; Gas emissions; Greenhouse gases; Risk assessment; Risk perception; Safety engineering; Storage (materials); Uncertainty analysis; Carbon dioxide

Authors: Luyk J., Karydas D.
Title: Availability and risk management in IGCC power generation plants: A structured approach for a non-mature technology
Source title: 9th International Conference on Probabilistic Safety Assessment and Management 2008, PSAM 2008
Affiliations: Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Luyk, J., Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Karydas, D., Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) is a technology used for power generation that combines coal gasification with the benefits of a combined cycle. It is a technology that, in combination with CO2 capture and storage, is one of the leading candidate solutions for future electricity production, as is acknowledged through many governmental and academic studies. IGCC as a technology for power generation is already applied worldwide within different plant configurations. The experience gained is mostly based on demonstration scale power generation plant operations, and is in a stage of marginal sustainability, regarding the transition of this technology into commercialization. The currently marginal sustainability, as well as the availability and risk management of IGCC power plants should be one of the main focal areas of the energy sector. Lessons learned from industry in this field can be found in literature. However, a structured approach to availability and risk management for IGCC, taking into account societal, human, and organizational influences, is clearly missing. In this paper, a structured approach to availability and risk management for IGCC plants is proposed. Specific areas of interest for IGCC, such as dealing with the scarcity of historical data specific to this technology, are discussed.
Author Keywords: Availability and risk management; Energy production and distribution; Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle
Index Keywords: Electricity production; Energy productions; Historical data; Integrated gasification combined cycle; Lessons learned; Power generation plants; Specific areas; Structured approach; Carbon dioxide; Coal gasification; Combined cycle power plants; Digital storage; Risk management; Safety engineering; Sustainable development; Technology

Authors: Assaf S., Guerich M.
Title: Influence of temperature on sound transmission through viscoelastic sandwich plates
Source title: Proceedings - European Conference on Noise Control
Affiliations: ESTACA, 34 rue Victor Hugo, 92300 Levallois Perret, France; ESILV, 92916 Paris la Défense, France
Authors with affiliations: Assaf, S., ESTACA, 34 rue Victor Hugo, 92300 Levallois Perret, France; Guerich, M., ESILV, 92916 Paris la Défense, France
Abstract: A numerical study to investigate the effects of temperature on the diffuse sound transmission loss (TL) of sandwich plates is presented. The numerical prediction tool used is based on a finite element formulation for the sandwich plate coupled to a boundary element method for the acoustic medium. The plate formulation is derived from Kirchhoff's theory for the elastic faces and Mindlin's theory for the core. The frequency-temperature dependence of the viscoelastic material properties are taken into account using an experimentally derived viscoelastic constitutive law. The results presented deal with a laminated glass subjected to a diffuse sound field. It is found that the dip of the TL curve at the coincidence frequency of the plate is totally removed for temperatures where this frequency is in the transition region of the used viscoelastic material. Indeed, the relative low value of the storage modulus and the high value of the loss factor in this region, induce high transverse shear deformations of the viscoelastic interlayer and thus high energy losses.
Index Keywords: Diffuse sound fields; Effects of temperature; Finite element formulations; Numerical prediction tool; Sound transmission loss; Transverse shear deformation; Visco-elastic material; Viscoelastic sandwich plates; Acoustic fields; Boundary element method; Energy dissipation; Viscoelasticity; Mindlin plates

Title: Thermodynamic and spectroscopic analysis of tert-butyl alcohol hydrate: Application for methane gas storage and transportation

Molecular Sci., Canada
Abstract: Since fuel gases such as methane, ethane, and hydrogen can be stored in solid hydrate form, clathrate hydrate research has been focused on using hydrates as a gas storage and gas transportation medium. To utilize gas hydrate as an energy storage and transportation medium, two important key features - storage capacity and storage conditions - must be considered. In this study, we describe the inclusion phenomena of methane occurring in a tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) hydrate through thermodynamic measurement and spectroscopic studies. The X-ray diffraction and NMR spectroscopic analysis revealed that a sII TBA hydrate (cubic, Fd3m) forms in the presence of methane but does not form the same structure in the presence of TBA alone. Under equilibrium conditions, the pressure-lowering effect of methane + tert-butyl alcohol di-hydrate was also observed. These results provide several key features for a better understanding of inclusion phenomena occurring in the complex hydrate systems and further developing methane or other gas storage and transportation techniques.

Authors: Djurado E., Rocha R.A., Bandara K., Alloin F., Djurado D.
Title: Zirconia based-nanofillers prepared by spray-pyrolysis for polymer electrolytes used in lithium batteries
Source title: A Global Road Map for Ceramic Materials and Technologies: Forecasting the Future of Ceramics, International Ceramic Federation - 2nd International Congress on Ceramics, ICC 2008, Final Programme
Affiliations: LEPMI, CNRS UMR 5631, Grenoble Université, 1130 rue de la Piscine, 38402 St. Martin d'Hères Cedex, France; Department of Physics, University of Peradeniya, Peradeniya, Sri Lanka; INAC, SPrAM, CEA Grenoble, 17 rue des Martyrs, 38054 Grenoble Cedex 9, France; IPEN, CCTM, CMDMC, Rua do Matão, travessa R 400, 05508-000, São Paulo - SP, Brazil

Abstract: Solid polyether matrix with lithium salts has attracted attention in the domain of energy storage systems as electrolytes for lithium batteries. To improve electrolyte efficiency, composite polyether-based electrolytes with inorganic ceramic additives have been prepared. Nanocomposite polymer electrolytes were prepared by solution casting method, based on the addition of ZrO2:Y2O3 nanostructured ceramics, obtained by spray-pyrolysis assisted by ultrasonic atomizer, to POE [poly(oxyethylene)] matrix with Li(CF3SO2)2N salt. The microstructure of the composite was observed by SEM and the influence of the addition of zirconia nanofillers on the polymer was investigated by XRD, DSC and complex impedance method.

Authors: Lumpkin G.R.
Title: Ceramics and the nuclear fuel cycle
Source title: A Global Road Map for Ceramic Materials and Technologies: Forecasting the Future of Ceramics, International Ceramic Federation - 2nd International Congress on Ceramics, ICC 2008, Final Programme
Affiliations: Institute of Materials Engineering, Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, Menai, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Lumpkin, G.R., Institute of Materials Engineering, Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, Menai, Australia
Abstract: Ceramics are considered by many to be very attractive alternatives to borosilicate glass for the long-term storage of high-level nuclear wastes in geological repositories. The available data show that advanced titanate ceramics and glass-ceramics are highly durable in aqueous systems at low temperatures and can be tailored to a range of applications in the nuclear fuel cycle. Recent developments point to glass-ceramics as materials that are capable of accommodating the chemical complexity of legacy wastes. Studies of radiation damage indicate that the titanate phases of interest become amorphous as a result of the gradual accumulation of alpha-recoil collision cascades, but this may not have a serious effect on aqueous durability. The ability to build in radiation tolerance in these materials is an important consideration for the development of waste forms, transmutation targets, and other materials for advanced nuclear energy systems. Pyrochlore and defect fluorite structure types are of particular interest in this regard and may be of particular relevance in the disposition of legacy Pu and other "minor" actinides in advanced nuclear energy systems. Likewise, monazite may also be of interest for future nuclear applications due to the ability to incorporate trivalent and tetravalent actinides, low dissolution rates, and radiation tolerance.
Index Keywords: Aqueous system; Chemical complexity; Collision cascade; Dissolution rates; Fluorite structure; High-level nuclear wastes; Legacy waste; Long-term storage; Low temperatures; Nuclear application; Nuclear energy systems; Nuclear fuel cycles; Pyrochlores; Radiation tolerances; Tetravalent actinides; Titanate ceramic; Waste forms; Actinides; Borosilicate glass; Digital storage; Geological repositories; Glass ceramics; Neutron detectors; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Phosphate minerals; Plutonium; Radiation damage; Legacy systems

Authors: Costa L.M., Bourry F., Kariniotakis G.
Title: Stochastic optimization techniques for the optimal combination of wind power generation and energy storage in a market environment

Abstract: This paper proposes a new method, based on stochastic optimization, for managing the operation of a wind farm in conjunction with energy storage. The main objective is to maximize the benefit of the joint operation of wind generators and energy storage devices, while considering the stochastic nature of wind power production and electricity market prices. The paper presents results of the application of the methodology in decision-making processes related to wind power management.

Authors: Jecu C., Teninge A., Roye D., Bacha S., Belhomme R., Bousseau P.
Title: Contribution to frequency control through wind turbine inertial energy storage
Source title: European Wind Energy Conference and Exhibition 2008
Affiliations: GIE IDEA, 961, rue de la Houille Blanche, 38402 Saint Martin d'Hères cedex, France; G2Elab, 961, rue de la Houille Blanche, 38402 Saint Martin d'Hères cedex, France; EDF R and D, 1, Avenue du General de Gaulle, 92141 Clamart cedex, France

Abstract: This paper presents an innovative way for wind energy to participate in some sort of frequency control using: - Kinetic energy stored in the rotor for a fast power reserve that could be delivered in a short period (from several seconds up to a few tens of seconds). This kinetic energy based fast reserve is ensured despite wind speed variations. - A dis-optimisation of the power coefficient through the modification of the rotor speed set point or through the pitch control. In case of a frequency drop the power coefficient could then be increased to produce more energy. This innovative way could help to reduce the dynamics and the depth of the frequency drops and therefore allow wind farms to participate in frequency control. As a future perspective for this work it is planned to perform an economic analysis of the cost of this fast power reserve provided by wind turbine as a function of the amount of reserve considered.
Index Keywords: Frequency drops; Future perspectives; Inertial energy; Pitch control; Power coefficients; Power reserves; Rotor speed; Setpoints; Short periods; Wind farm; Wind speed; Drops; Economic analysis; Electric utilities; Exhibitions; Kinetic energy; Kinetics; Wind turbines; Wind power

Authors: Ummels B.C., Pelgrum E., L.kling W., Droog H.
Title: Energy storage options for system integration of offshore wind power in the Netherlands
Source title: European Wind Energy Conference and Exhibition 2008
Affiliations: Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; TenneT TSO, Netherlands; TenneT TSO Transition Platform Sustainable Electricity Supply, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Ummels, B.C., Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; Pelgrum, E., TenneT TSO, Netherlands; L.kling, W., Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; Droog, H., TenneT TSO Transition Platform Sustainable Electricity Supply, Netherlands
Abstract: For the system integration of foreseen large-scale offshore wind power in the Netherlands, investments in certain energy storage options may become necessary. In this paper, the results are presented of a explorative system study for the Netherlands' power supply in 2020. The system integration of large-scale wind power is assessed in combination with four options for large-scale energy storage. The study is performed by Delft University of Technology for the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Transition Platform Sustainable Electricity Supply. It is shown that for the set of basic assumptions applied for this study, the system integration of future foreseen large-scale wind power does not necessitate the development of energy storage. This conclusion is shown to be highly sensitive to assumptions regarding international exchanges and the functioning of international markets on short time-scales. Different energy storage alternatives are likely to provide significant opportunities for the reduction of total system costs. This benefit comes at the expense of additional CO2-emissions at the system level, due to energy conversion losses inherent to energy storage and the additional operation of base-load coal-fired plants at the expense of peak-load gas-fired plants, the latter of which produce less CO2 on a MWh-basis.

Authors: Rogut J., Steen M.
Title: Hydrogen oriented underground gasification of coal
Source title: 25th Annual International Pittsburgh Coal Conference, PCC - Proceedings
Affiliations: GIG, Central Mining Institute, Plac Gwarkow 1, 44-100 Katowice, Poland; Institute for Energy, Joint Research Centre, European Commission, Westerduingweg 3, 1755 ZG Petten, NL, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Rogut, J., GIG, Central Mining Institute, Plac Gwarkow 1, 44-100 Katowice, Poland; Steen, M., Institute for Energy, Joint Research Centre, European Commission, Westerduingweg 3, 1755 ZG Petten, NL, Netherlands
Abstract: Underground coal gasification (UCG) is a technology with more than one century of history. Recently, it has attracted renewed interest triggered by increasing global energy security concerns and stringent environmental regulations on energy production from fossil fuels. HUGE, the Hydrogen Oriented Underground Coal Gasification for Europe project, co-financed by the European Coal and Steel Research Fund is a major clean coal technology R&D project in the European Union. HUGE raises high expectations because of the potential of its specific UCG concept to integrate large scale in situ production of hydrogen-rich gases with on site geological storage of carbon dioxide. This would allow transferring underground generated low carbon and partly purified hydrogen or synthesis gases to the surface as major product, while leaving behind the wastes generated during their conversion from coal. The project, which primarily addresses a European issue, also has a global dimension because of the environmental constraints related to the technologies involved. Major attention in the technology oriented project HUGE is paid to optimizing the integration of mature elements of coal gasification and hydro-gasification processes with heat and mass transfer phenomena taking place in geological multiphase systems of complex geometry. Because the coal to hydrogen conversion process may be carried out at high depths in the composite geological structures of coal seams, aquifers and surrounding strata, only a limited number of methods and tools are available for controlling the conversion processes. Hence, valuable expertise from in situ coal gasification, from geological carbon dioxide storage, from geothermy and from enhanced oil recovery are compiled, critically assessed and used as building blocks in designing and constructing the hydrogen oriented UCG plant. In the context of HUGE, the novel concept of geo-reactor, which stands for an underground, environmentally safe coal gasification plant intentionally integrated with geothermal heat exchange and with carbon capture and storage, is investigated for exploitation of synergies between various geological technologies.
Index Keywords: Building blockes; Carbon capture and storage; Carbon dioxide storage; Clean coal technologies; Coal seams; Complex geometries; Conversion process; Energy productions; Enhanced oil recovery; Environmental constraints; Environmentally safe; European Union; Gasification process; Geological storage; Geological structures; Geothermal heat; Global dimension; Global energy; Heat and mass transfer; In-situ; In-situ production; Low carbon; Multi phase systems; Novel concept; Underground coal gasification; Underground gasification; Aquifers; Carbon dioxide; Carbon monoxide; Carbonization; Coal; Coal deposits; Coal gasification; Coal gasification plants; Coal industry; Coal research; Enhanced recovery; Environmental regulations; Fossil fuels; Gas generators; Gas producers; Hydrogen; Hydrogen storage; Hydrogeology; Mass transfer; Metal recovery; Steel research; Synthesis gas; Technology; Coal storage

Authors: Chen Y., Athienitis A.K., O'Neill B., Galal K.E.
Title: Design and thermal performance of a solar house with BIPV/T system, thermal storage and passive solar heating
Source title: American Solar Energy Society - SOLAR 2008, Including Proc. of 37th ASES Annual Conf., 33rd National Passive Solar Conf., 3rd Renewable Energy Policy and Marketing Conf.: Catch the Clean Energy Wave
Affiliations: Solar Buildings Research Network, Dept. of Building, Civil and Environmental Engineering, Concordia University, 1455 De Maisonneuve Blvd., West Montreal, QC, H3G 1M8, Canada

Abstract: This paper describes the design and thermal performance assessment of a solar house with a building-integrated photovoltaic-thermal system (BIPV/T), passive solar design and a hollow core concrete for solar heat storage. The house was designed to achieve close to net-zero annual energy consumption. Several innovative solar technologies are adopted in this house to meet the design goal. Building integrated photovoltaic-thermal systems (BIPV/T) collects thermal energy from the heated solar photovoltaic panels and cools them down at the same time, thus also increasing their electricity production. Ventilated concrete slab stores part of the collected thermal energy in the heating season and is also used for night cooling with exterior cool air at nighttime in the cooling season. Large south facing windows together with passively charged and released concrete slab and walls are employed for passive solar spacing heating. An integrated supervisory control system is used to optimize the integrated performance of conventional mechanical system and solar energy systems. The house was completed in Dec. 2007 and preliminary results are presented.
