Authors: Brons J.
Title: T5 high-bays and metal halide face-off
Source title: Lighting Design and Application: LD and A
Affiliations: Kauffman Consulting, LLC, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Brons, J., Kauffman Consulting, LLC, Australia
Abstract: The Lighting Research Center (LRC) published the results of a demonstration of a six-lamp T5 fluorescent lighting system with wireless motion-sensing lighting controls. LRC tested the performance and energy efficiency of the system in a high-bay environment, as compared with an existing metal halide lighting system. The T5 fluorescent lighting system was retrofitted in several storage aisles at a distribution center warehouse in Albany, NY. The Demonstration and Evaluation of Lighting Technology and Applications (DELTA) program at LRC evaluated the system to compare illuminances, energy usage, and worker feedback of the earlier metal halide lighting with three different light levels from the T5 fluorescent lighting system. It also gathered worker feedback regarding the performance of the motion sensors when controlling each luminaire individually against those that are grouped by aisles.

Authors: Gusdorf J., Douglas M.A., Swinton M., Szadkowski F., Armstrong M.
Title: Testing a 6 kWe natural gas internal combustion cogeneration unit at the Canadian Centre for housing technology
Affiliations: Natural Resources Canada, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Gusdorf, J., Natural Resources Canada, Canada; Douglas, M.A.; Swinton, M.; Szadkowski, F.; Armstrong, M.
Abstract: Residential combined heat and power (CHP or cogen) systems have several potential advantages over centralized electricity generation. By generating electricity in or near a residence, a cogen system makes it possible to capture the waste heat and use it for space heat and hot water, thus significantly reducing fuel use and greenhouse gas emissions. Applied on a large scale, cogen systems can result in distributed generation, which can reduce line losses, and reduce or eliminate the need for new power plants and transmission lines. This paper describes the testing of a Japanese natural gas fired internal combustion unit with nominal outputs of 6 kW electrical and 11.7 kW thermal. The unit can be programmed to follow the electrical load of a house, or for constant output. It was installed at the Canadian Centre for Housing Technology in a system that allowed electrical energy to be exchanged with the grid. Thermal energy could be sent to storage tanks for use as hot water and space heat, or sent to a borehole. Electrical and thermal outputs and efficiencies are defined under electrical load-following and constant outputs, and when sending heat to storage tanks, the borehole and both. These tests have provided data that can be used for detailed modelling of the unit's performance, and for optimizing its operation under various conditions of electrical and thermal energy demands, and prices of natural gas and electricity.

Authors: Khan S.
Title: Small and large scale UGSFs
Affiliations: Gazprom, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Khan, S., Gazprom, Russian Federation
Abstract: A growing number of countries start developing underground gas storage facilities (UGSF). UGSF are well-developed in Asia, e.g., China, India, Pakistan, and Iran. As for the number of UGSF, US takes the lead with 385 UGSF. The biggest cumulative working gas capacity may be observed in Russia and the US. Each UGSF performs its particular function, i.e., controls gas streams, ensures gas supply to entire regions or smoothes out gas consumption fluctuations in separate cities and towns. Thus, UGSF vary in size - from a million cubic meters to dozens billion cubic meters in terms of working gas capacity. UGSF size is strongly affected by market conditions. However, such conditions are related to the existing geological conditions, either favorable or unfavorable. Further development of UGSF is stipulated by the objective conditions of the evolving market, as well as environmental and operational safety requirements. Renewable sources of energy, e.g., wind, tides, tidal bores, and solar energy, may also be the impetus for underground storage development, synchronizing electric power generation and consumption. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the International Gas Union Research Conference (Paris, France 10/8-10/2008).

Authors: Van Gemert W.
Title: Energy management for the consumer - Meeting national energy targets
Affiliations: Hanze University of Applied Science, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Gemert, W., Hanze University of Applied Science, Netherlands
Abstract: The energy demand in EU is for a big deal covered by fossil sources. About 25% of total consumption is represented by natural gas. Based on estimates made by IEA, this will grow at around 40% by 2050. Part of natural gas is converted to electricity; part is directly delivered to the end users. A discussion covers the targets on energy use; large scale electricity storage; energy storage in the downstream part; and investment costs, for example, of the water fall lake to be built in the North Sea. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the International Gas Union Research Conference (Paris, France 10/8-10/2008).

Authors: Kang S.-P., Seo Y.
Title: Natural gas storage in mesoporous media using gas hydrate
Affiliations: Gasification Research Centre, Korea Institute of Energy Research, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kang, S.-P., Gasification Research Centre, Korea Institute of Energy Research, South Korea; Seo, Y.
Abstract: KIER (Korea Institute of Energy Research) has been conducting investigations into storing methane or natural gas in variety of materials and methods last 10 years with the goal to develop this technology on a practical and economical basis. An alternative method of storing natural gas in gas hydrates is being studied for providing a safe and economic means to cope with peak load demands of electric power plant. To establish this method as an industrial gas storage process, existing problems should be resolved, that is, the rapid gas hydrate formation and the minimized induction time. In this work we tried and investigated the feasibility of gas storage method by using porous material as a storage media. It was expected that porous material could provide huge amount of contact area between water and gas molecules so that higher rate and amount of gas consumption could be achieved. In this report, we measured the equilibrium dissociation pressures of methane and natural gas hydrates in silica gel pores at first. As the pore sized diameter of silica gel particles becomes smaller, the inhibition effect of equilibrium dissociation pressures of each hydrate goes larger. Based on the equilibrium data, the gas consumption along time was also measured and the results were transformed into the rate and amount of geis consumption during hydrate formation by using isobaric method. There was nearly no induction time for hydrate formation in silica gel pores as simplified porous material, which can be affirmatively used to gas storage method.

Authors: Goulden B., Hadlock C.
Title: Modeling and assessment of a natural gas fired CHP with integrated diurnal storage system
Affiliations: Union Gas Limited, Canada; Enermodal Engineering, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Goulden, B., Union Gas Limited, Canada; Hadlock, C., Enermodal Engineering, Canada
Abstract: Union Gas is an Ontario-based Canadian integrated natural gas storage, transmission and distribution utility. It is in the process of constructing three new commercial style service centre buildings at separate locations in Ontario. These buildings are expected to be completed by the end of 2009. Each building will use a different type of gas fired cogeneration; waste heat will also be utilized differently in each building with one of the three buildings including absorption cooling. All three buildings will be LEED certified and will incorporate a number of innovative design features. In order to increase the expected overall energy efficiency, each building also features diurnal thermal storage. This feature will allow the buildings to "sleep" outside of regular office hours and on weekends (when the buildings will be typically unoccupied) by utilizing the waste heat generated during cogeneration operation for space conditioning during off-hours. One building; (Burlington, Ontario) will utilize four 65 kW microturbines, another, a 350 kW reciprocating engine and another, a 200 kW microturbine. The discussion and analysis herein is limited to only the first building, namely the four 65 kW microturbines. The planned diurnal storage capacity for this building is 70 m3 of water. Results are provided for the dynamic hourly modeling of the cogeneration system for the micro turbine-equipped building throughout the winter heating (3700 HDD) and summer cooling (305 CDD) season. Dynamic modeling over the entire annual operating cycle allows for an assessment of the microturbine/ diurnal storage impacts during all seasons including "shoulder months" in the spring and fall when the weather is more temperate. The analysis discusses the relative merits of operating the CHP system to track the electrical demand of the building with surplus heat stored for use by building systems as well as operating the microturbines continuously with the additional power generated exported and sold to the provincial electricity grid. The dynamic modeling scenarios considered (through the full annual operating cycle) include a number of different equipment and operating scenarios: 1) CHP system operating at full capacity with surplus power exported to the grid 2) CHP system operating to meet the building's electric power demand (electrical load-following) 3) Scenario's 1 and 2 above re-run without the diurnal storage capacity The modeling results showed that there were clear operating savings associated with diurnal storage. Not surprisingly, running the generators at full capacity with a net-metering buy-back scheme is less attractive than running the generators using load-following; as the buy-back rate increases, there is a tipping-point where full capacity runs make economical sense. An unanticipated result was that although the day-time grid demand can be effectively eliminated, the current building operating strategy will result in significant night time power demand. Consideration will be given to changing the building operating strategy to reduce these loads.

Authors: Grappe J.
Title: UGS technology improvements: Some answers of the UGS industry to the evolution of gas markets Oral speaker
Affiliations: Géostock, 7, rue E. et A. Peugeot, 92563 Rueil-Malmaison Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Grappe, J., Géostock, 7, rue E. et A. Peugeot, 92563 Rueil-Malmaison Cedex, France
Abstract: Underground storage is a technology applied since 1915 to the storage of large quantities of compressed natural gas (CNG). The main options available encompass reservoir storage in oil and gas fields or in aquifers, and storage in salt leached caverns. Underground natural gas storage (UGS) facilities developed rapidly and ensured originally a triple role of securing strategic supply, covering seasonal swing in demand and contributing to overall optimisation of the gas grid management. The technology used in the UGS industry called on proven solutions originating mainly from the oil and gas industry. As gas markets developed, and quite recently as an answer to drastic changes entailed by the liberalisation of the gas industry in mature gas countries, the UGS industry had to call on new techniques and approaches to answer new challenges in terms of performance, flexibility, safety, environmental impact, societal acceptance and economic efficiency. New technology was introduced for upgrading the existing UGS to more flexible and efficient storage facilities and for implementing new generation grass root UGS projects; and innovative approaches were developed in the field of usage and marketing of UGS. The corresponding innovation effort consisted mainly in the improvement of existing techniques or the adaptation of technology used in other industries (such as the Oil and Gas Exploration and Production or the Information Technology). In parallel, new types of UGS facilities emerged to overcome the absence of geological conditions suitable to the more traditional UGS techniques, in areas where a need for storage capacity had been identified (CNG storage in lined rock caverns), or to answer storage demand for new products (LNG storage in underground lined caverns, storage of DME produced by Gas -or Coal- to Liquid conversion processes or storage of Hydrogen). Additionally, new forms of underground storage of energy are currently investigated such as Adiabatic Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES), whereas the storage of CO2 which widely calls on UGS storage techniques, contributes to trigger a large R&D effort with a view to bridge the gap between the time scale applicable to underground storage of natural gas and the much longer time frame required to be considered for CO2 sequestration. Based on the above, the UGS industry is believed to have a bright future, combining the continuous improvement of its more conventional techniques to serve evolving natural gas markets, and the development of innovative new underground storage techniques to safely and economically store the energy of tomorrow.

Authors: Batisse R., Cuni A., Wastiaux S., Briottet L., Lemoine P., De Dinechin G., Chagnot C., Castilan F., Klosek V., Langlois P., Vrel D., Girodon-Boulandet N., Weinberger B.
Title: Investigation of X80-steel grade for hydrogen gas transmission pipelines
Affiliations: GDF SUEZ, France; Air Liquide; CEA (LITEN); CEA (LTA); CEA-CNRS (Laboratory Leon Brillouin); CNRS (LIMHP)
Authors with affiliations: Batisse, R., GDF SUEZ, France; Cuni, A., Air Liquide; Wastiaux, S., Air Liquide; Briottet, L., CEA (LITEN); Lemoine, P., CEA (LITEN); De Dinechin, G., CEA (LTA); Chagnot, C., CEA (LTA); Castilan, F., CEA (LTA); Klosek, V., CEA-CNRS (Laboratory Leon Brillouin); Langlois, P., CNRS (LIMHP); Vrel, D., CNRS (LIMHP); Girodon-Boulandet, N., CNRS (LIMHP); Weinberger, B., CNRS (LIMHP)
Abstract: Energetic security as well as limitation of greenhouse effect are major challenges concerning future populations. Hydrogen gas, both as energetic vector and as non-greenhouse gas, is therefore of prime interest to help solve them: it can indeed be produced by numerous sources (natural gas, nuclear power-plants, coke,...) and also by different renewable energies (biomass, solar, wind-machines). However, in specific conditions, hydrogen gas can weaken metallic materials, notably high strength steel containing ferritic phases; From about twenty years ago, high ferritic-pearlitic steel grade like X80, has been developed and is nowadays used for new natural gas transmission pipelines at high pressure. Some money is saved through wall thickness reduction and eased time-consuming welding. But this high strength steel is not yet selected for hydrogen gas pipelines which are limited to low and medium grades to avoid risks of brittle failures by hydrogen interaction. The "CATHY-GDF" project explores the ability of commercial X80 steel grade for transmission or storage of high pressurised hydrogen gas in large diameter pipeline (36′). The project focuses on base metal as well as girth weld in high hydrogen gas pressure environment. This 3-year project is granted by the French National Agency for Research and brings together French industrial and academic partners: GDF Suez, CEA, Air Liquide, and CNRS-LIMHP*. This paper focuses on first results of laboratory mechanical testing of X80 materials in high hydrogen gas pressure environment and describes a new experimental apparatus to simulate hydrogen pipe behaviour.

Authors: Ruban G.N., Khan S.A.
Title: Sequestration of gas industrial emission
Affiliations: VNIIGAZ, Russian Federation; GAZPROM
Authors with affiliations: Ruban, G.N., VNIIGAZ, Russian Federation; Khan, S.A., GAZPROM
Abstract: Natural gas share in the power balance of Russia is 60 %. In underground gas storage sector and operation of gas transportation system there are following sources of pollution: booster compressor stations, gas distribution stations, boilers, production wells, gas pipelines, etc. Though one of the major source of atmospheric contamination is automobile transport. To reduce the share of emissions in atmosphere, injection of industrial gases into geological reservoirs and depleted fields may be used. For this purpose underground gas storage construction technologies may be employed. Technological process of industrial emissions sequestration has several stages: catching, concentrating, transporting and storing. CO2 as a component of power plant gaseous emissions is the major chemical substance which is to be injected into reservoirs. This work treats physical and chemical processes in a layer caused by industrial gases injection, with regards to changes in electro-kinetic and thermodynamic properties. Surface of a solid particle which comes in contact with aqueous electrolyte (formation water) spontaneously acquires a surface electric charge which is compensated by counter-ions. As a result, a double electric layer (DEL) is formed on the edge of interface «solid - liquid - gas». Formation of DEL takes place spontaneously as a consequence of surface energy approaching to a minimum and in connection with specific properties of interface «solid - liquid - gas». Movement of phases under external mechanical force leads to displacement of charges and to occurrence of potential gradient in a direction of displacement. To characterize this potential in pore structure the concept of Τ-potential is used. Due to comprehensive investigations of physical, chemical, electrokinetic, corrosive phenomena and reservoir properties observed during injection of CO2 and liquefied gas mixtures in a reservoir, the movement of CO2/water or liquefied gas mixture/water front can be mapped by means of computer tomogram. With the objective of full scale testing the core storage from all Russian UGS was organized, and sampling of gas industrial emissions discharged at different compressor operation stages was provided. As soon as leakages of industrial emissions stored in a reservoir may occur during the storage period, much attention should be paid to risk minimization. The former investigations enable using UGS construction and operation experience to prevent leakage risks. To evaluate leakage risks associated with gas industrial emissions sequestration in depleted oil & gas fields and storage sites constructed in compliance with UGS construction technologies in porous formations methods and routines accepted for UGS are used. For gas leakage elimination, a monitoring and remedial strategy is adopted. The available monitoring methods prove to be efficient. The environmental monitoring procedure complies with methods and regulations adopted in gas industry. To carry out the environmental monitoring the source data on environment contamination by production facilities is provisioned. This research has the objective of studying behavior of gases injected into system of layers under influence of mineralized formation water, high temperatures and pressure.

Authors: Khaloshin O., Tolmachev V., Sidorov S.
Title: Methodolgy and technology aspects of establishing infrastructure and sales market and of efficient utilization of gas from small untapped fields in the South Federal Disrict of the Russian Federation
Affiliations: OAO Gazprom Promgaz, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Khaloshin, O., OAO Gazprom Promgaz, Russian Federation; Tolmachev, V., OAO Gazprom Promgaz, Russian Federation; Sidorov, S., OAO Gazprom Promgaz, Russian Federation
Abstract: The paper presents the results of the Promgaz energy market expansion methodology aimed at: Using gas recoverable from small untapped fields as an energy resource; Studying the factors modifying energy demand in the areas around such fields conditioned by the existing civil engineering infrastructure; Creating databases and procedures to find basic solutions for the use of gas recoverable from such fields to generated electric and heat energy. The research to implement a commercially viable use of natural gas from small untapped fields was done for the RF Southern Federal District. Ways and means were developed to assess various fuel infrastructure options practicability with regard to local conditions. Scrutinized options included handling gas from small fields as trunk-pipeline gas, compressed gas, liquefied gas, synthetic liquid fuel, as well as its underground storage. The scenarios accounted for the gas shortage, the combustibles infrastructure development prospects and the existing gas grids.

Authors: Lempérière F.
Title: The Emerald Lakes: Large offshore storage basins for renewable energy
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Affiliations: Hydrocoop, 4 Cité Duplan, Paris F-75116, France
Authors with affiliations: Lempérière, F., Hydrocoop, 4 Cité Duplan, Paris F-75116, France
Abstract: Large offshore basins are called as Emerald Lakes, as they have the potential to store large volumes of sea water and use them to generate renewable energy when required. The use of sea as a basin has emerged as the basis for many potential solutions for obtaining the necessary storage volume. One such solution is based on dams built along the shore where structures around 50 meters high and operated between 30 and and 50 meters above the sea level, can store around 1.5 GWh per km2 with a full basin. Many cliff areas can provide another potential solution where a large basin with high dykes can be built on a 100 meters high cliff, as the upper parts of the cliffs are relatively flat. It is also essential to evaluate the the necessary additional investments or costs of renewable energies as compared with the use of fossil fuel before undertaking such projects around the world.
Index Keywords: Offshore basin; Potential solutions; Renewable energies; Storage volumes; Fossil fuels; Investments; Lakes; Landforms; Sea level; Seawater; Renewable energy resources

Authors: Kamphuis R., Kok K., Warmer C., Hommelberg M.
Title: Architectures for novel energy infrastructures: Multi-agent based coordination patterns
Source title: 2008 1st International Conference on Infrastructure Systems and Services: Building Networks for a Brighter Future, INFRA 2008
Affiliations: Energy Research Centre of the Netherlands, ECN, Westerduinweg 3, P.O. Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands; VITO, Flemish Institute for Technological Research, Mol, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Kamphuis, R., Energy Research Centre of the Netherlands, ECN, Westerduinweg 3, P.O. Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands; Kok, K., Energy Research Centre of the Netherlands, ECN, Westerduinweg 3, P.O. Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands; Warmer, C., Energy Research Centre of the Netherlands, ECN, Westerduinweg 3, P.O. Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands; Hommelberg, M., VITO, Flemish Institute for Technological Research, Mol, Belgium
Abstract: Due to the increased proportion of small renewable energy sources in a distributed setting (DG-RES), active control of small distributed energy producing and consuming systems will play an important role in future electricity grids [1]. These distributed energy resources have production patterns, which are either partially stochastic (e.g. wind, solar cells) or are coupled to the primary user process (e.g. co-generation of heat and electricity). Furthermore, on the demand-side, and increasingly on the electricity storage side, opportunities exist for actively serving stability applications in the grid by real-time supply/demand coordination. In the future, an information and communication layer for grid coordination could serve a portfolio of ICT-applications on timescales running from seconds to hours. To get a grip on these (r)evolutionary developments, possibly toppling the electricity grid, in this paper, architecture requirements for future high proportion DG-RES electricity grids are collected from a Power Electronics System point of view as well as from an ICT point of view using an inventory of business models in the power grid that focus on coordination of multiple small-scale DG-RES resources. Modeled from an ICT point-of-view, these give rise to architectures for applications that can successively be implemented in hardware and software as active components in the distribution grid. A number of possible grid control strategy coordination patterns (GCPs), which are defined in a generic, reusable manner, can be seen to emerge. GCPs, connected and intertwined to one another on several layers (physical, commercial) of the grid, together, can provide the framework for coordination in the overall intelligent grid. Bottom-up approaches of implementing coordination in future active grids appear to be the method of choice to use in implementing the GCPs. Software agents [2], [3] coordinating primary processes using market algorithms, as implemented in the PowerMatcher approach [3]-[4], appear to be very suited for this.
Index Keywords: Active components; Active control; Bottom up approach; Business models; Co-generation; Demand-side; Distributed energies; Distributed Energy Resources; Distribution grid; Electricity grids; Energy infrastructures; Evolutionary development; Grid control; Hardware and software; Heat and electricity; Information and communication; Multi-Agent; Power electronics systems; Power grids; Production patterns; Renewable energy source; Time-scales; Control system analysis; Electric energy storage; Energy resources; Galerkin methods; Power electronics; Power generation; Software agents; Wind power; Solar energy

Authors: Bresesti P., Kling W.L., Vailati R.
Title: Transmission expansion issues for offshore wind farms integration in Europe
Source title: Transmission and Distribution Exposition Conference: 2008 IEEE PES Powering Toward the Future, PIMS 2008
Affiliations: CESI Ricerca, Grid and Infrastructures Department, via Rubattino 54, 20134 Milan, Italy; Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; TenneT TSO bv, Arnhem, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Bresesti, P., CESI Ricerca, Grid and Infrastructures Department, via Rubattino 54, 20134 Milan, Italy; Kling, W.L., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands, TenneT TSO bv, Arnhem, Netherlands; Vailati, R., CESI Ricerca, Grid and Infrastructures Department, via Rubattino 54, 20134 Milan, Italy
Abstract: This paper presents an overview of the major issues concerning the expansion of the European transmission system for the connection and for the integration of offshore wind farms. These issues are basically related to: i) the connection solutions for offshore wind farms (infrastructures at sea), ii) the reinforcement of the onshore transmission system for accommodating the power produced by the wind farms, while guaranteeing system security, and iii) the options for facilitating transmission investments (definition of priority projects, funding support schemes, regulatory frameworks). Concerning the first issue, we compare two connection solutions with reference to a 100-MW offshore wind farm: 150 kV alternating current (AC) and high voltage direct current based on voltage sourced converters (VSC-HVDC). An economic assessment takes into account the investment, operation and maintenance costs, and the negative valorization of losses and energy not supplied. As far as the second issue is concerned, we describe the prospects for the development of offshore wind farms and, taking into account the characteristics of the existing European wind and hydro pumped-storage facilities and a possible wind-hydro combination, we discuss the need for system reinforcement. With regard to the third issue, we present the options and instruments which exist and which are under discussion in order to facilitate transmission expansion investments, such as the list of electricity projects of common interest prepared by the European Commission and the regulatory framework of tenders for licensing offshore electricity transmission in the United Kingdom (UK). ©2008 IEEE.
Author Keywords: DC power transmission; Energy storage; Interconnected power systems; Power transmission; Power transmission economics; Power transmission planning; Pumped storage power generation; Wind power generation

Authors: Lakeman B., McGowan B., Wilson M., Gunter W.
Title: A Canadian framework for advancing CO2-EOR projects and managing risks associated with CCS activities
Source title: Energy Institute - 19th World Petroleum Congress 2008: A World in Transition: Delivering Energy for Sustainable Growth
Affiliations: Alberta Research Council, Canada; Penn West Energy Trust, Canada; University of Regina, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Lakeman, B., Alberta Research Council, Canada; McGowan, B., Penn West Energy Trust, Canada; Wilson, M., University of Regina, Canada; Gunter, W., Alberta Research Council, Canada
Abstract: Canadian governments and industry developed a supportive policy, regulatory, and fiscal framework for CO2 capture and storage projects. This framework includes the development of greenhouse gas offset quantification protocols associated with CO2-EOR projects. Combined, these developments are helping Canada demonstrate its progress towards environmentally sustainable energy production and increasing public and stakeholder confidence around commercial CO2 capture and geological storage projects. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 19th World Petroleum Congress (Madrid, Spain 6/29/2008-7/3/2008).

Authors: Tondeur D., Teng F.
Title: Carbon capture and storage for greenhouse effect mitigation
Affiliations: Laboratoire des Sciences du Génie Chimique, CNRS ENSIC-INPL, 1 rue Grandville BP 451, 54001 Nancy, France
Authors with affiliations: Tondeur, D., Laboratoire des Sciences du Génie Chimique, CNRS ENSIC-INPL, 1 rue Grandville BP 451, 54001 Nancy, France; Teng, F., Laboratoire des Sciences du Génie Chimique, CNRS ENSIC-INPL, 1 rue Grandville BP 451, 54001 Nancy, France
Abstract: The capture of carbon dioxide from flue gases of industrial combustion processes and its storage in deep geological formations is now being seriously considered as one of the options for mitigating climate change. This chapter presents the overall background on which this approach is based, then reviews the different capture technologies and finally discusses the different options for underground storage. Carbon dioxide is responsible for about 60% of the present-day additional radiative forcing in the atmosphere. CCS has an important and inevitable energy cost, implying that when it is applied, more primary energy is needed and, ultimately, more CO2 is generated to produce a given amount of final energy. Carbon dioxide capture has been applied to industrial gas streams for almost a century, for process purposes but not for storage purposes. The main applications were "sweetening" of natural gas and treatment of "synthesis gas" for the manufacture of ammonia and methanol. In the present context, CO2 captures producing a concentrated stream of CO2, suitable for transport and subsequent storage, starting with dilute effluents. There are a number of potential geological reservoirs that can be considered as storage options for captured CO2. These storage options include depleted oil and gas fields, CO2 enhanced oil recovery (EOR), CO2 enhanced gas recovery (EGR), CO2 enhanced coal-bed methane recovery (ECBM), deep saline aquifers and other storage options. There is little experience of combining capture, transport and storage of CO2 in a fully integrated system, and none applied to large-scale power plants. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved.

Authors: Jens E., Thompson L.
Title: Wind energy for electric power generation on Mars and other planets
Source title: International Astronautical Federation - 59th International Astronautical Congress 2008, IAC 2008
Affiliations: University of Melbourne, Parkville, Australia; RMIT University, Bundoora, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Jens, E., University of Melbourne, Parkville, Australia; Thompson, L., RMIT University, Bundoora, Australia
Abstract: This paper presents an alternate viable solution to the problem of reliable power supply in interplanetary missions by evaluating the efficacy of harnessing wind energy to power remote installations. Although initially conceived for use in powering a manned Martian base, this paper shows that the technology is potentially viable on Venus and hence transferable to other extraterrestrial planets and moons that have an atmosphere and differential heating. A metaanalysis of existing publications investigating Martian and Venus atmospheric conditions provided a theoretical model which was used as the framework for the operating conditions of a vertical axis wind turbine. After exploration of existing wind and ocean turbine technologies, vertical axis wind turbine design theory was applied and developed for use on Mars and Venus. A prototype of the vertical axis wind turbine design was subsequently prepared and tested to determine its viability for providing sustainable power. Consideration was given to the volatile nature of both the Martian and Venusian climates as well as to the ease of deployment, storage, and transport of the vertical axis wind turbine system. The vertical axis wind turbine design allowed the conception of an innovative deployment technique which facilitated low launch mass and volume.
Index Keywords: Atmospheric conditions; Differential heating; Extraterrestrial planets; Interplanetary mission; Launch mass; Meta-analysis; Operating condition; Reliable power supply; Sustainable power; Theoretical models; Turbine technologies; Vertical axis wind turbines; Viable solutions; Wind energy; Design; Electric power generation; Electric power systems; Extraterrestrial atmospheres; Interplanetary flight; Oceanography; Planets; Wind turbines; Wind power

Authors: Le May I.
Title: Structural integrity and petrochemical industry
Source title: Energy Materials: Materials Science and Engineering for Energy Systems
Affiliations: Metallurgical Consulting Services Ltd, PO Box 5006, SK S7K 4E3, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Le May, I., Metallurgical Consulting Services Ltd, PO Box 5006, SK S7K 4E3, Canada
Abstract: The importance of engineering structural integrity in the petrochemical industry, which has broader implications for energy applications, is discussed in the context of the history of many serious accidents that have taken place in refineries, storage facilities and processing plants in recent years. A number of critical incidents from around the world are reviewed, and several cases investigated in North America are cited. These demonstrate the important role of well conducted regular inspections, based on sound advanced planning, in maintaining in service assessment of fitness for purpose of plant. The significant contribution of risk based inspection procedures, together with the need for a sound knowledge of potential degradation mechanisms, is emphasised. Finally, it is noted that there is a need for a safety conscious organisational culture underpinned by robust, relevant and continued training and development, for the entire workforce including management and supervisory staff. © 2009 Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining.
Author Keywords: Degradation and corrosion; Engineering structural integrity; Failure analysis; Inspection; Petrochemical industry

Authors: Min H., Yi S., Heo J., Kim B., Cho Y., Hong J.
Title: Slab-based memory management scheme for sensor operating system
Source title: IASTED International Symposium on Distributed Sensor Networks, DSN 2008
Affiliations: School of Computer Science and Engineering, Seoul National University, 599, Sinlim 9-dong, Gwanak-gu, Seoul, South Korea; School of Computing, Soongsil University, 511, Sangdo-dong, Dongjak-gu, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Min, H., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Seoul National University, 599, Sinlim 9-dong, Gwanak-gu, Seoul, South Korea; Yi, S., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Seoul National University, 599, Sinlim 9-dong, Gwanak-gu, Seoul, South Korea; Heo, J., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Seoul National University, 599, Sinlim 9-dong, Gwanak-gu, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, B., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Seoul National University, 599, Sinlim 9-dong, Gwanak-gu, Seoul, South Korea; Cho, Y., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Seoul National University, 599, Sinlim 9-dong, Gwanak-gu, Seoul, South Korea; Hong, J., School of Computing, Soongsil University, 511, Sangdo-dong, Dongjak-gu, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Previous dynamic memory allocation schemes that had been researched for general purpose operating system cannot directly apply to the wireless sensor networks (WSNs). Because these schemes did not consider features of WSNs and its applications, they consume a lot of energy caused by long execution times, and waste the memory space caused by fragmentation. In this paper, we found features of WSNs applications and made the model which adapts these issues. Through this research, we suggest the slab allocator that reduces the execution time and the memory management space. Also, we evaluate the performance of our scheme by comparing to one of the previous systems.
Author Keywords: Dynamic memory management; Performance evaluation; Sensor operating system; Slab
Index Keywords: Allocators; Dynamic memory allocation; Dynamic memory management; Execution time; General purpose; Memory management; Memory space; Operating systems; Performance evaluation; Computer operating systems; Energy conversion; Sensor networks; Storage allocation (computer); Wireless sensor networks

Authors: Baek J.-Y., Jeong H., Song J.D., Lee M.-H., Kim S.B., Kim G.S.
Title: Excimer laser induced photoresist stripping on the silicon wafer
Source title: ICALEO 2008 - 27th International Congress on Applications of Lasers and Electro-Optics, Congress Proceedings
Affiliations: Environment and Energy Division, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology, CheonAn, 330825, South Korea; Manufacturing System Division, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology, CheonAn, 330825, South Korea; QSI (Quantum Semiconductor International) Co., South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Baek, J.-Y., Environment and Energy Division, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology, CheonAn, 330825, South Korea; Jeong, H., Manufacturing System Division, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology, CheonAn, 330825, South Korea; Song, J.D., QSI (Quantum Semiconductor International) Co., South Korea; Lee, M.-H., Environment and Energy Division, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology, CheonAn, 330825, South Korea; Kim, S.B., Environment and Energy Division, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology, CheonAn, 330825, South Korea; Kim, G.S., Environment and Energy Division, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology, CheonAn, 330825, South Korea
Abstract: There is a growing interest to develop a new cleaning technology to preclude the undesirable effects of wet cleaning technologies such as environmental pollution and the low cleaning efficiency on the modern electronic industry and data storage industry. Laser cleaning is a potential technology to remove various pollutants on a wafer surface. The stripping of the photoresist (PR) layer on a silicon wafer was investigated by using the line beam of a KrF excimer laser with a wavelength of 248 nm. The silicon wafer surfaces were measured by a scanning electron microscope (SEM) and the compositions of the PR covered wafers were determined by an energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). PR layers with various thickness were removed perfectly at an energy density of 600 mJ/cm2 after a 30-pulse irradiation or less. The EDS results show that the PR layer was removed more than 95%. This study has shows that the laser dry cleaning technology has the superior ability on the PR stripping without any silicon wafer damage.
Index Keywords: Cleaning efficiency; Cleaning technology; Data storage industry; Electronic industries; Energy density; Environmental pollutions; KrF excimer laser; Laser cleaning; Photoresist stripping; Potential technologies; Pulse irradiation; Scanning electron microscopes; Silicon wafer surface; Undesirable effects; Wafer surface; Wet cleaning; Dry cleaning; Energy dispersive spectroscopy; Excimer lasers; Gas lasers; Krypton; Photoresistors; Scanning electron microscopy; Semiconducting silicon compounds; Stripping (dyes); Surface cleaning; Surface treatment; Technology; Silicon wafers

Authors: Taljan G., Canizares C., Fowler M., Verbič G.
Title: Study of mixed wind-nuclear-hydrogen power plants
Affiliations: University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Ljubljana, Slovenia; University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Taljan, G., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Ljubljana, Slovenia; Canizares, C., University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada; Fowler, M., University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada; Verbič, G., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: A novel methodology for economic evaluation of hydrogen storage for a mixed wind-nuclear power plant considering some novel aspects such as residual heat and oxygen utilization is presented in this paper. The simulation of the operation of the combined nuclear-wind-hydrogen system is discussed first, where the selling and buying of electricity, the selling of excess oxygen, and the selling of heat from the stationary fuel cells is optimized to maximize profits, in the context of existent markets for all these services and products. The simulation is done in two phases: In the predispatch phase, the system model is optimized to obtain optimal hydrogen charge levels for the given operational horizons. In the second phase, a real-time dispatch is carried out on an hourly basis to optimize the operation of the system as to maximize profits, following the storage levels of the predispatch phase. Based on the operation planning and dispatch results, an economic evaluation is performed to determine the feasibility of the proposed scheme for investment purposes; this evaluation is based on calculations of modified internal rates of return and net present values for a realistic scenario. The results of these studies demonstrate that the use of hydrogen for the sole purpose of storage of electricity, in spite of oxygen and heat utilization and considering current hydrogen production and utilization technologies, is not economically feasible at this time. ©2008 IEEE.

Authors: Marsh P., Pomeroy J., Pohl S., Quinton W., Onclin C., Russell M., Neumann N., Pietroniro A., Davison B., McCartney S.
Title: Snowmelt processes and runoff at the arctic treeline: Ten years of MAGS research
Source title: Cold Region Atmospheric and Hydrologic Studies. The Mackenzie GEWEX Experience
Affiliations: National Water Research Institute at NHRC, 11 Innovation Blvd., Saskatoon, SK S7N 3H5, Canada; Centre for Hydrology, University of Saskatchewan, 117 Science Place, Saskatoon, SK S7N 5C8, Canada; Cold Regions Research Centre, Wilfrid Laurier University, Waterloo, ON N2L 3C5, Canada; University of British Columbia Okanagan, Kelowna, BC V1V 1V7, Canada; National Water Research Institute, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Marsh, P., National Water Research Institute at NHRC, 11 Innovation Blvd., Saskatoon, SK S7N 3H5, Canada; Pomeroy, J., Centre for Hydrology, University of Saskatchewan, 117 Science Place, Saskatoon, SK S7N 5C8, Canada; Pohl, S., National Water Research Institute at NHRC, 11 Innovation Blvd., Saskatoon, SK S7N 3H5, Canada; Quinton, W., Cold Regions Research Centre, Wilfrid Laurier University, Waterloo, ON N2L 3C5, Canada; Onclin, C., National Water Research Institute at NHRC, 11 Innovation Blvd., Saskatoon, SK S7N 3H5, Canada; Russell, M., National Water Research Institute at NHRC, 11 Innovation Blvd., Saskatoon, SK S7N 3H5, Canada; Neumann, N., University of British Columbia Okanagan, Kelowna, BC V1V 1V7, Canada; Pietroniro, A., National Water Research Institute at NHRC, 11 Innovation Blvd., Saskatoon, SK S7N 3H5, Canada; Davison, B., National Water Research Institute at NHRC, 11 Innovation Blvd., Saskatoon, SK S7N 3H5, Canada; McCartney, S., National Water Research Institute, Canada
Abstract: Under the Mackenzie GEWEX Study, extensive snowmelt and runoff research was carried out at the Trail Valley and Havikpak Creek research basins at the tundra-forest transition zone near Inuvik, Northwest Territories. Process based research concentrated on snow accumulation, the spatial variability of energy fluxes controlling melt, local scale advection of sensible heat from snow-free patches to snow patches, percolation of meltwater through the snowpack, storage of meltwater in stream channels, and hillslope runoff. Building on these studies, process based models were improved, as shown by a better ability to model changes in snow-covered area during the melt period. In addition, various landsurface and hydrologic models were tested, demonstrating an enhanced capability to model melt related runoff. Future research is required to accurately model both snow-covered area and runoff at a variety of scales and to incorporate topographic and vegetation effects correctly in the models. © 2008 Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.

Authors: Bauer A., Gyenge E.L., Oloman C.W.
Title: Templated electrodeposition of Pt-Ru nanoparticles on fibrous carbon substrates in the presence of nonionic surfactant: Application for methanol oxidation
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of British Columbia, 2216 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Bauer, A., Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of British Columbia, 2216 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada; Gyenge, E.L., Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of British Columbia, 2216 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada; Oloman, C.W., Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of British Columbia, 2216 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada
Abstract: Pt-Ru nanoparticles were electrodeposited onto three-dimensional graphite felt substrates utilizing liquid crystalline and micellar aqueous solutions of the nonionic surfactant Triton X-100 to produce novel anode structures for direct methanol fuel cells. The effect of surfactant concentration, deposition time and current density was studied employing a factorial experimental design. Obtained electrocatalysts were characterized by SEM, EDX and ICP-AES. Cyclic voltammetry, chronoamperometry and chronopotentiometry were carried out to assess the catalytic activity for methanol oxidation. Pt-Ru deposited using 6 mA cm2, 90 minutes and 40 %wt Triton X-100 yielded superior performance. Preliminary fuel cell tests highlighted the importance of an ion-conducting network across the thickness of the three-dimensional anode. Both single electrode and fuel cell tests demonstrated that templated deposition yields better catalyst utilization based on mass activity compared to plating from solutions without surfactant.

Authors: Navone C., Baddour-Hadjean R., Pereira-Ramos J.-P., Salot R.
Title: Electrochemical behaviour of oriented V2O5 films for rechargeable lithium microbatteries prepared by dc sputtering
Affiliations: Institut des Sciences Chimiques Seine Amont, LECSO, UMR CNRS 7582, 2 rue Henri Dunant 94320, Thiais, France; Institut des Sciences Chimiques Seine Amont, LADIR, UMR CNRS 7075, CNRS, 2 rue Henri Dunant, 94320 Thiais, France; LITEN/DTEN/STN/LTME, CEA Grenoble, 17 rue des Martyrs, 38054 Grenoble, France

Abstract: V2O5 films have been prepared by a reproducible dc sputtering method and their electrochemical behavior is examined and discussed in relation with their morphological and structural features. Special attention is paid on the influence of preferred orientation on the electrochemical response of the deposit. Results indicate that the h00 preferred orientation ensures a good homogeneity for Li insertion-extraction and then a high rechargeability. Indeed, the capacity only changes from 80 to 73 μ Ah/cm 2 after 100 cycles and is still of 70 μh/cn2 after 200 cycles.

Title: Magnetic properties of orthorhombic Li3Fe2(PO 4)3 phase
Affiliations: Institut des Nanosciences de Paris (INSP), Université Pierre et Marie Curie, UMR-CNRS 7588, 140 rue de Lourmel, 75015 Paris, France; Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Koszykowa 75, 00-662 Warsaw, Poland; Département Mathématiques, Informatique, Physique, Planète et Univers (MIPPU), CNRS, Campus Boucicaut, 140 rue de Lourmel, 75015 Paris, France

Abstract: Orthorhombic Li3Fe2(PO4)3 powders were synthesized by a wet chemical process using iron nitrate as precursors. The effect of synthesis procedure and heat-treatment temperature on the purity, grain size and crystal structure was studied. The resulting powders were characterized by magnetic measurements including SQUID magnetometry and EPR spectroscopy. Magnetic measurements clearly revealed that Li3Fe 2(PO4)3 exhibits a paramagnetic to antiferromagnetic phase transition at TN=28 K. Curie-Weiss-like behaviour is observed above this temperature. In addition, magnetization data M(H) suggest that ferromagnetic particles are also present in the Li 3Fe2(PO4)3 powders.

Affiliations: Ruder Boskovic Institute, P.O. Box 3430, 1001 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Bernstorff, S., Sincrotrone Trieste, ss. 14, Basovizza, 34012 Trieste, Italy
Abstract: V/Ce oxide films on glass substrate were obtained by sol-gel process. The morphology of these nanostructured and porous films was studied by grazing-incidence small-angle X-ray scattering (GISAXS). The aim of the GISAXS study was to investigate the changes in grain sizes and porosity V/Ce oxide at 55 at. % of V, due to the intercalation of Li+ ions. We found that the effects of the introduced Li are twofold. First, he size of particles is reduced from 3.3 to 2.2 nm while the size distribution width is increased from 1.3 to 1.6 nm. Secondly the surface is smoothed and it's contribution to the scattering is dominating. The particle size is the greatest at the surface and decreases with the depth, and this is not influenced by intercalation although the relative rate in change is bigger in the intercalated sample.

Abstract: LiFeP2O7 was synthesized by a wet chemical process using and iron nitrate as precursors. The effect of synthesis procedure and heat-treatment temperature on the purity, grain size and crystal structure was studied. The resulting powders were characterized by various techniques including structural and magnetic measurements. Magnetic experiments exhibit the antiferromagnetic transition at TN=27 K. The electrochemical features were investigated showing that lithium insertion in the Li 1+xFeP2O7 phase provides a practical capacity of 98 mAh/g.

Abstract: The lithium pyrophosphates of divalent transition metals LiM 1.5P2O7 (M=Ni, Co, Mn, Cu) have been synthesized by a solid state reaction. The resulting powders were characterized using XRD, FTIR, Raman and SQUID magnetometer. Fingerprints of the P-O-P bridging bonds are observed in FTIR spectra which display an asymmetric stretching around 750 cm-1. XRD data show that LiC 1.5P2O7 is not isostructural with LiN 1.5P2O7 but isomorph to α-CO 2P2O7. Magnetic experiments exhibit the antiferromagnetic transition near TN=11 K. The effective magnetic moment μeff of LiN1.5P2O7 and LiM1.5P2O7 compounds is in agreement for octahedral the Ni2+ and Mn2+ions.
Index Keywords: Antiferromagnetic transition; Asymmetric stretching; Bridging bonds; Effective magnetic moments; FT-IR spectrum; FTIR; Isostructural; Lithium intercalation materials; Magnetic features; SQUID magnetometers; XRD; Antiferromagnetism; Energy storage; Flywheels; Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy; Lithium; Magnetic moments; Magnetometers; Manganese; Manganese compounds; Nanostructured materials; Solid state reactions; Transition metals; X ray diffraction; X ray diffraction analysis; Magnetic storage

Authors: Gyenge E.L., Lycke D.R.
Title: Preparation of unsupported Pt-Sn nanoparticles on three-dimensional electrodes by an electrophoretically assisted Bönnemann method: Application for direct ethanol fuel cell anodes
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Gyenge, E.L., Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada; Lycke, D.R., Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada
Abstract: Unsupported Pt-Sn nano-particles were deposited on graphite felt electrodes using both the colloidal Bönnemann method and a novel, electrophoretically assisted modification employing a superficial current density of 1.25 mA cm-2. It was found that the conventional Bonnemann method was not effective for depositing practical colloidal metal loadings (e.g. above 0.1 mg cn-2) on the three-dimensional monolithic substrate. The application of a small superficial current density of 1.25 mA cm-2 increased the Pt-Sn load on the felt to ∼1 mg cm-2. Pt:Sn atomic ratios in solution of 0.5:1, 1:1, 2:1 and 9:1 were evaluated for deposition. The electrophoretically assisted deposition using a solution with a 9:1 Pt:Sn atomic ratio produced a catalyst on the graphite felt with a 4.7:1 Pt:Sn ratio. The latter showed good performance for ethanol electro-oxidation as determined by cyclic voltammetry and chronopotentiometry. The Pt-Sn effective surface area was determined by the Cu underpotential deposition and stripping method.
Index Keywords: Assisted deposition; Atomic ratio; Chronopotentiometry; Colloidal metals; Effective surface area; Ethanol electro-oxidation; Graphite felts; Monolithic substrates; SN ratio; Stripping methods; Three-dimensional electrode; Underpotential deposition; Colloidal graphite; Cyclic voltammetry; Energy storage; Ethanol; Ethanol fuels; Felt; Felts; Flywheels; Fuel cells; Graphite; Graphite electrodes; Nanoparticles; Nanostructured materials; Stripping (dyes); Three dimensional; Tin; Platinum

Title: Structural and magnetic properties of glassy phosphates with nasicon-like framework
Affiliations: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Koszykowa 75, 00-662 Warsaw, Poland; Institut des Nano-Sciences de Paris (INSP), CNRS-UMR 7588, Université Pierre et Marie Curie, 140 me de Lourmel, 75015 Paris, France

Abstract: The structural and magnetic properties of vitreous materials containing transition metal cations - LixM2(PO4) x (M = Fe, V, Mo and x = 3, 5, 6, respectively) which crystallize with the Nasicon-like structure have been studied. Information concerning local cationic environments and configuration of (PO4)3- polyanions and P-O-P bridges have been concluded from Raman and Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy investigations. The vibrational spectrum of LixM2(PO4)x is dominated by two very strong and broad bands located in mid-infrared and in the far-infrared range. A third band is attributed to the P-O-P ring of P2O 5 glass former. Studies of the magnetic susceptibility have been carried out by Superconducting Quantum Interference Device (SQUID) measurements. Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility of the samples with Fe- and V- containing compounds follows a Curie-Weiss model at room-temperature and below down to Néel point. For the Mo-based compounds, a different behavior has been observed; this material behaves as diamagnetic in the whole range of temperature.
Index Keywords: Broad bands; Far-infrared; Glass former; Information concerning; Midinfrared; Nasicon; Nasicon-like structures; Polyanions; Room temperature; Structural and magnetic properties; Superconducting quantum interference device; Temperature dependence; Transition metal cations; Vitreous materials; Energy storage; Flywheels; Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy; Magnetic susceptibility; Molybdenum; Nanostructured materials; Neon; SQUIDs; Superconducting magnets; Transition metals; Materials properties

Abstract: Structural features of phospho-olivine structures are investigated by local probes such as FTIR and Raman scattering spectroscopy. Lithium iron phosphate LiFePO4 and its isostructural LiXPO4 compounds (X=Ni, Co, Mn) are considered. The local cationic arrangement is discussed with the aid of a molecular vibration model to figure out the bonding between FeO6 octahedra and (PO4)3- groups. A relationship is establish between the v3 stretching mode frequency and the second ionisation potential of the transition metal in the LiXPO4 framework.

Affiliations: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Koszykowa 75, 00-662 Warsaw, Poland; Institut des Nano-Sciences de Paris, Université Pierre et Marie Curie, UMR-CNRS 7588, 140 rue de Lourmel, 75015 Paris, France

Abstract: A series of compounds Li1+yMn2-yo4 with 0.00≤y≤0.33 were synthesized using a sol-gel method from succinate precursors. Impurity-free nanostructured powders were obtained by heat-treatment at 700 °C in ambient atmosphere. Structural properties have been investigated by X-ray diffractometry and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. The substituted spinels keep the same symmetry Fd3m in the whole domain of substitution. Variation of the cubic parameter is compared with the different spectroscopic parameters extracted from the FTIR spectra. Compositional dependence of band frequencies, oscillator strength, and mode splitting show the evolution of the covalency as a function of the cationic substitution in the spinel lattice.

Authors: Salah A.A., Jozwiak P., Garbarczyk J., Gendron F., Mauger A., Julien C.M.
Title: FTIR features of lithium iron phosphates used as positive electrodes in rechargeable lithium batteries
Affiliations: Institut des Nano-Sciences de Paris (INSP), Université Pierre et Marie Curie, UMR-CNRS 7588, 140 rue de Lourmel, 75015 Paris, France; Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Koszykowa 75, 00-662 Warsaw, Poland; Département Mathématiques, Informatique, Physique, Planète et Univers (MIPPU), CNRS, Campus Boucicaut, 140 rue de Lourmel, 75015 Paris, France

Abstract: The essential structural features of lithium metal phosphates (LMP) have been studied using FTIR spectroscopy which is a sensitive tool to probe the local environment in the solids. Various LMP materials where M is iron have been investigated including phospho-olivine LiFePO4, diphosphate LiFeP2O7, Nasicon-type phosphate Li3Fe 2(PO4)3 and dihydrate FePO4-2H 2O. Vitreous and amorphous materials are also considered. Analysis of internal and external modes of vibration allows to distinguish between the different phases and the type of cationic environment in the framework. Results corroborate the contribution of the main factors which are responsible for the complexity of the spectra, i.e. departure from ideal symmetry, interactions between polyhedra, bridging atoms, lattice distortion, etc.

Title: Nanocomposite polymer electrolytes based on poly(methylmethacrylate)- γ-Al2O3
Affiliations: Electronic Materials Division, National Physical Laboratory, Dr. K. S. Krishnan Marg, New Delhi-12, India; Materials Research Lab., Dept. of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia, New Delhi-25, India

S. Krishnan Marg, New Delhi-12, India
Abstract: Polymer electrolytes, which hold the key of successful operation of all solid state ionic devices, have been investigated. The polymer used was amorphous poly (methyl methacrylate) and the gel polymer electrolyte based on it exhibited room temperature conductivity >10-3 S/cm. Further these electrolytes were transformed into composites by dispersing inert inorganic particles 11nm in size of γ-Al2O3 in varying wt % (0-10 wt.%). An enhancement in the conductivity obtained for few samples is described in terms of free charge carrier concentration. It has been realized that the mechanical integrity of these composites increases many fold, without decreasing the conductivity.

Affiliations: Département de Chimie, Université du Québec à Montréal, Succursale Centre-Ville, Montréal, QC H3C 3P8, Canada

Abstract: Carbon black was modified by in situ generated diazonium salt. The tetrafluoroborate salts that were used to modify the surface were: +N2C6H4-SO3H, +N2C6H4-N(C2H 5)2, +N2C6H 4-COOH and +N2C6H 4-CF3. The surface of the modified carbon was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, XPS. The average surface concentration of functionalities detected by XPS is about 2 at. %, meaning that the nature of the group in para of the phenyl ring does not seem to influence the grafting mechanism.

Authors: Lana-Villarreal T., Alonso-Vante N.
Title: Photoinduced charge transfer between TiO2 particles and Ru xSey clusters: A photocatalytic performance improvement
Affiliations: Departament de Química Física, Institut Universitari d'Electroquímica, Universitat d'Alacant, Apartat 99, E-03080, Alacant, Spain; Laboratoire de Electrocatalyse, UMR 6503 CNRS, Université de Poitiers, F-86022 Poitiers Cedex, France

Abstract: TiO2 particles were modified with the chalcogenide (Ru xSey) cluster-like nanoparticles. For both TiO2 suspensions and layers containing RuxSey an enhancement of the photogenerated electron consumption via oxygen reduction was observed. The chalcogenide nanoparticles in colloidal form were able to accumulate electrons photogenerated under UV illumination. The kinetics for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) of RuxSey, as catalyst, either in colloidal form or as nanoparticles deposited onto the titanium dioxide surface, was favored. This ORR process is essential, though most photocatalyic reactions are limited by the electron consumption in presence of molecular oxygen.

Abstract: In this work, we study the evolution of the ESR signal as a function of the average oxidation state of manganese ions from 3.5+ to 4+ for a series of lithium-rich manganate spinels Li1+yMn2-yO4 (with 0.00<y<0.33) synthesized by wet-chemical technique from succinate precursors. Resonance spectra exhibit only a broad band of 300 mT at room temperature, while two bands are observed at low temperatures with bandwidth of 55 and 3 mT, respectively. All broad bands deviate from the classical Lorentzian shape. The occupation of extra Li+ ions in 16d sites and of the replacement of larger Mn3+ ions by smaller Mn4+ ions are analyzed and the local structure is discussed according the MnO6 octahedra distortion in the spinel lattice.
Index Keywords: Broad bands; Electron spin resonance; Local structure; Lorentzian shapes; Low temperatures; Manganese spinels; Oxidation state of manganese; Resonance spectrum; Room temperature; Spinel lattices; Wet chemical techniques; Wet chemistry; Electron spin resonance spectroscopy; Energy storage; Flywheels; Ions; Lithium; Manganese compounds; Nanostructured materials; Resonance; Spin dynamics; Manganese

Authors: Baddour-Hadjean R., Pereira-Ramos J.-P.
Title: Raman spectroscopy for investigating local structural changes in lithium intercalation compounds
Affiliations: Institut Des Sciences Chimiques Seine-Amont, LADIR, UMR 7075 CNRS, Université Pierre et Marie Curie, 2 rue Henri Dunant, 94320 Thiais, France; Institut Des Sciences Chimiques Seine-Amont, LECSO, UMR 7582 CNRS, 2 rue Henri Dunant, 94320 Thiais, France
Authors with affiliations: Baddour-Hadjean, R., Institut Des Sciences Chimiques Seine-Amont, LADIR, UMR 7075 CNRS, Université Pierre et Marie Curie, 2 rue Henri Dunant, 94320 Thiais, France; Pereira-Ramos, J.-P., Institut Des Sciences Chimiques Seine-Amont, LECSO, UMR 7582 CNRS, 2 rue Henri Dunant, 94320 Thiais, France
Abstract: In this paper, we demonstrate the interest of Raman spectroscopy to describe the local changes occurring in cathodic materials as electrochemical lithium insertion proceeds. Two examples are developed (i) the L xV2O5 system produced from V2O 5 thin films (ii) the Li/TiO2 anatase system investigated as a composite electrode. The evolution of the Raman spectra upon Li intercalation indicates local structural and chemical changes. For the first time, the Raman fingerprints of the different lithiated phases in the Li/V 2O5 and Li. TiO2 systems are clearly evidenced. Moreover, in the case of lithiated titanate, the theoretical analysis of the spectroscopic data based upon lattice dynamics calculation has allowed to propose a complete interpretation of the experimental Raman spectra of the lithiated phase. This provides valuable information on the Li atom positions and coordination. In particular, the high wavenumber Raman modes in the 900-950 cm-1 range can be assigned to the stretching vibrations of rather short Li-O bonds. The existence of such strongly bonded Li-O entities accounts for the partial rechargeability of the anatase TiO2 system.
Index Keywords: Anatase TiO; Cathodic materials; Chemical change; Composite electrode; Electrochemical lithium insertion; Lattice dynamics; Li atoms; Li intercalation; Lithium Intercalation; Raman modes; Raman spectra; Spectroscopic data; Stretching vibrations; Structural change; TiO; Wave numbers; Crystal lattices; Energy storage; Flywheels; Intercalation compounds; Lithium compounds; Nanostructured materials; Raman scattering; Raman spectroscopy; Solids; Spectroscopic analysis; Stretching; Titanium dioxide; Lithium

Authors: Singh C.P., Vyas O.P., Tiwari M.K.
Title: An overview of routing protocols of sensor networks
Source title: 2008 International Conference on Computational Intelligence for Modelling Control and Automation, CIMCA 2008
Affiliations: Comp. Science and IT Department, Dr. C. V. Raman University, Bilaspur, India; School of Studies In Comp. Science, Pt. RSU, Raipur, India
Authors with affiliations: Singh, C.P., Comp. Science and IT Department, Dr. C. V. Raman University, Bilaspur, India; Vyas, O.P., School of Studies In Comp. Science, Pt. RSU, Raipur, India; Tiwari, M.K., School of Studies In Comp. Science, Pt. RSU, Raipur, India
Abstract: Recent advances in wireless sensor networks have led to various original protocols purposely designed for sensor networks where energy awareness is an essential deliberation. Most of the attention, however, has been given to the routing protocols since they might differ depending on the application and network architecture. Tiny sensor nodes form sensor network. These nodes are severely constrained by energy, storage capacity and computing power. The prominent job of this network is to propose skillful routing protocols for to make the node's life last longer. In this paper, we first explore the necessities of sensor networks and its architecture. Then, we explain to the existing routing protocols for sensor networks and present a significant study of these protocols. The paper concludes with open research issues. At the end of this paper, we evaluate and contrast these protocols. © 2008 IEEE.

Authors: Prendes N., Menéndez E.
Title: Digital image processing and MEB (BSE) techniques in the identification and quantification of minerals phases present in cement and concrete
Affiliations: Petrology and Mineralogy, Cedex-Ministerio de Fomento, Madrid, 28026, Spain; Materials, Instituto Torroja, Madrid, 28021, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Prendes, N., Petrology and Mineralogy, Cedex-Ministerio de Fomento, Madrid, 28026, Spain; Menéndez, E., Materials, Instituto Torroja, Madrid, 28021, Spain
Abstract: The processes of generation of images in Backscattered Scanning Electron Microscopy (BSE) are governed by complex interactions between incident electrons beam within the specimen. Different authors have correlated the energy released by the electron beam impact with the mean atomic number (Z) of the sample to study, and deduced that the nature of the scattering events induced by the electron beam is strongly controlled by the Z value. If we compare the amount of electron backscattering with respect to the response to the beam energy, and so deduce a mathematical function, for each specimen studied, using digital image processing (based on the linear transformation of grey levels range in those energies), it is possible to improve the discrimination and quantification of some phases in cements that, due to overlapping processes, until now, could not be isolated. Through these theoretical studios it is possible, for example, to identify interstitial cations that affect the Z factor of the phase, deducing for each type of energy emitted a series of mathematical functions, whose coefficients are fitted with the use of digital image techniques, allowing to improve the discrimination and quantification of certain phases in cements that appear visible as grey levels in a digital image. The electron microscope has to be set up very precisely (DW=10 mm, V0=20 KeV), being possible then to determine, from a pattern specimen, the grey levels of image histogram for those working conditions, and fit the data using a linear function - when operating in backscattering mode - that takes into account the theoretic phases deduced from the EDX (Energy Dispersive X-Ray) and the quantitative analysis of the stoichiometric formula. Given a coefficient (η) its effective Z is calculated; the measured deviation, therefore, gives the interstitial cations presence. With this tool, for example, the ettringite of gypsum is discriminated; as well as C-S-H products and C3S. Once the grey levels of the image of the surface of the sample are obtained, it is immediate to deduce by means of threshold images process (a value of limit grey level or phase identification) stereological relations (working with planar surfaces, which facilitate the treatment and the development of algorithms of mathematical morphology) and quantitative values for each phase. © 2008 Materials Research Society.
Index Keywords: A-coefficient; Atomic numbers; Back-scattered; Beam energies; Cement and concretes; Complex interaction; Digital image; Digital image processing; Digital image technique; Electron backscattering; Energy dispersive x-ray; Ettringites; Grey levels; Image histograms; Incident electrons; Interstitial cations; Linear functions; Linear transformation; Mathematical functions; Overlapping process; Phase identification; Planar surface; Quantitative analysis; Quantitative values; Scattering events; Working conditions; Z value; Atoms; Backscattering; Blind source separation; Cements; Digital image storage; Electron beams; Gypsum; Image processing; Imaging systems; Mathematical morphology; Mathematical transformations; Positive ions; Scanning electron microscopy; Electrons

Authors: Ahn M.H., Lee S.C., Lee K.J.
Title: A study on methodology of optimal characterization and disposal priority for low and intermediate level radioactive wastes (LILWs) in Korea
Source title: International Conference on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants, ICAPP 2008
Affiliations: Department of Nuclear and Quantum Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 373-1, Kusong-dong, Yusong-gu, Daejeon, 305-701, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Ahn, M.H., Department of Nuclear and Quantum Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 373-1, Kusong-dong, Yusong-gu, Daejeon, 305-701, South Korea; Lee, S.C., Department of Nuclear and Quantum Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 373-1, Kusong-dong, Yusong-gu, Daejeon, 305-701, South Korea; Lee, K.J., Department of Nuclear and Quantum Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 373-1, Kusong-dong, Yusong-gu, Daejeon, 305-701, South Korea
Abstract: The Korea Hydro and Nuclear Power Co. (KHNP) has generated about 67,000 drums (200 L) of low and intermediate level radioactive waste (LILW) stored in the temporary storage facility at each reactor sites since 1977. The amount of dry active wastes (DAW) has been accumulated around 36,600 drums. The amount of evaporator bottoms (concentrated wastes), spent resin, and spent filters has been accumulated around 19,000 drums, 9,700 drums, and 1,600 drums. In this study, four mandatory items for the radioactive characterization of LILW were proposed such as the total activity, surface dose, individual activity, and surface contamination. The required contents of physical characterization were suggested with the weight (density), voidage, free liquid, and homogeneity. For chemical characterization, the teachability, corrosiveness, explosiveness, and chelation were demanded. Finally, the compressive strength and integrity of drum were requested for the mechanical characterization. To determine the disposal priority of LILW in Korea, two main parameters of waste management in Korea and overseas case studies were only considered. After considering those, the disposal priority of LILW was established as following: (1) concentrated wastes solidified with the cement and DA W whose radioactivity level is very low and detailed characterization can be readily identified, (2) spent resin solidified with the cement, (3) spent filters, (4) DA W whose radioactivity level is relatively high but the characterization is well documented, (5) the wastes that require the additional researches including spent resin in H1C, evaporator bottoms and concentrated waste solidified with the paraffin, and DAW contained with some harmful materials.
Index Keywords: Chemical characterization; Intermediate level; Main parameters; Mechanical characterizations; Nuclear power; Physical characterization; Radioactivity level; Reactor site; Spent filters; Surface contaminations; Surface dose; Temporary storage; Voidage; Cements; Compressive strength; Energy conversion; Evaporators; Industrial waste treatment; Nuclear energy; Nuclear industry; Nuclear power plants; Paraffin waxes; Paraffins; Radiation; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive wastes; Radioactivity; Resins; Waste disposal; Radioactive waste disposal

(KHNP) has generated about 67,000 drums (200 L) of low and intermediate level radioactive waste (LILW) stored in the temporary storage facility at each reactor sites since 1977.
